Course Title: Introduction to Health Science and Public Health (FS)
Description: This course offers an introduction to the art and science of public health and health sciences. The course describes the public health and healthcare systems in the United States, identifies disciplines of public health and health science, and explores the interrelationship between environmental factors, human behavior, and health policy in determining health outcomes. Cross-listed with PUBH110, may be taken once for credit.

Provides an introduction to disaster and emergency response systems and procedures used when environmental disasters or other emergencies strike. Students will learn the Incident Command System that is the basis for disaster response in the U.S. and around the world. They will also learn best practices for communicating with the public during times of an emergency, working effectively with community partners, and managing staff and volunteers while ensuring their safety. Students will develop a public health preparedness plan and earn five FEMA certificates in emergency management.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of junior or higher

Description: Learn how global health is practiced around the world, comparing systems and programs. Gain in-depth understanding of the international architecture for global health and global health decision-making. Learn tools and methods to apply global health. Appraise the diversity and content of global health areas of specialization.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Design of experiments, methods of analysis, interpretation and communication of results, and use of research to support evidence-based practice. Cross-listed with PUBH382, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Increase capacity to understand, plan, and implement governmental and organizational level policies related to health, safety, and wellbeing.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Identify data that can be used to answer practical questions, effectively present findings, and use facilitation skills to help groups make data-driven decisions and develop data-informed action plans.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of the biological, psychological, social, environmental, and cultural factors that influence health and wellbeing. Introduces models, theories, and public health methods associated with determinants of health. Topics include gender, ethnicity/race, relationships, socioeconomic status, built environment, community, political systems, stress and adverse childhood experiences, and culture and their influences on individual and community health. Cross-listed with PUBH305, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Course Title: Health Informatics and Data Management I
Description: Principles for the management of health data and considerations to achieve data integrity, interoperability, and information governance. Focus on clinical information systems, health data acquisition and storage, management tools, standards and quality, and decision support.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Upper-division students may earn credits in independent study, usually through directed reading or by completing a special project. Students may earn no more than 4 credits in a semester and no more than 6 credits during a single academic year, and no more than a total of 9 credits may be used to meet degree requirements or university graduation requirements. Before enrolling for independent study, a student must obtain the approval of the department chair, acting on the recommendation of the instructor who will be supervising the independent study. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken.

Risk assessment or risk management methods in disaster preparedness planning will be presented in context of natural and human-caused disasters. The environmental, economic, and social consequences for communities will be studied.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Provides an overview of methods and efforts to achieve measurable improvements in the efficiency, effectiveness, performance, accountability, outcomes, and other indicators of quality in services or processes, which achieve equity and improve the health of the community.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Description: Introduces various public health and health care disciplines and their functions. Information on educational requirements, opportunities, and advancement for each discipline. Explores disciplinary traits, values, and ethics in alignment with student skills, interests, and goals. (Pass/Fail)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Independent research at the doctoral level resulting in a dissertation that must be defended as a final oral examination and archived in the university library and with UMI. The dissertation must be written in clear and effective English and presented in a format that conforms to the standards of the Graduate College. Pass/fail only.

First-year Health Professions Living Learning Community participants will learn about the campus and community resources, explore various health-related professions and participate in service projects. May be repeated for credit.
Prerequisites: Admitted to Living Learning Community

Description: Study of fundamentals of nutrition as a factor in maintaining good health. Present day problems in nutrition are also discussed.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: An early assessment of a student’s potential to complete a doctoral program satisfactorily. Considerable autonomy is granted to the academic unit in the design, administration, and evaluation of the preliminary examination. Pass/fail only.

Nonprofits and government agencies use grant funding to support and expand programs. Learn the essential components of the donor development cycle, identifying potential grant funders, writing a successful grant proposal, and developing a compelling case for funding.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of junior or higher

Description: Internship opportunities in health sciences and public health are available through the department. May be repeated up to 12 credits.

Course Title: Thriving, Not Just Surviving: Cultivating Well-Being in College
Description: Using science-backed frameworks, provides tools to navigate the challenges of college life with greater clarity, purpose, and a sense of fulfillment. Empowers students to build meaningful relationships, and discover personal growth, laying the groundwork for a flourishing future.

Introduction to practices of health and wellness emphasizing lifestyles and measures of health. Covers general concepts related to the human body and chronic and infectious diseases, as well as how organ systems are affected by disease. Cross-listed with PUBH355, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Description: Provides an in-depth exploration of public health issues and interventions tailored to rural communities. Examine the unique challenges and opportunities in promoting health and preventing disease within rural populations, focusing on strategies to address disparities and improve overall well-being. Gain a comprehensive understanding of the unique public health challenges facing rural communities and develop skills to design, implement, and evaluate effective interventions to improve population health outcomes in rural areas. Cross-listed with PUBH425, may be taken for credit once.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Course Title: Epidemiology for Clinical and Public Health Practice
Description: Epidemiological principles and their practical applications in clinical and public health settings. Study of the distribution and determinants of disease within human populations. Provides tools to critically assess, interpret, and apply epidemiological data to improve healthcare and public health outcomes. Cross-listed with PUBH480, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Research conducted by a graduate student under the supervision of a member of the graduate faculty. Requires the clear statement of a hypothesis or proposition, a review of the relevant literature, analysis and synthesis of data or scholarly evidence, and the inference of conclusions. The results must be stated in a report written in clear and effective English. Requires submission of an Application for Directed Research prior to the deadline specified in the academic calendar. Either graded or pass/fail.
Students, working in interdisciplinary teams, engage in problem solving and communication activities that address current health related issues, Limited to COHS majors.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  NURS416 - Community and Population Health Nursing (3)

Or the co-requisites listed.
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
HLTH480 - Epidemiology for Clinical and Public Health Practice (3)
PUBH480 - Epidemiology (3)
RADSCI311 - Radiobiology and Protection (3)
RESPCARE323 - Neonatal and Pediatric Respiratory Care (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Background, objectives, scope, methods, and timeline of the dissertation research. Considerable autonomy is granted to the academic unit in the design, administration, and evaluation, and approval of the dissertation proposal. Pass/fail only.

Explores the development of interventions aimed at public health prevention, with an emphasis on collaborating with local communities in the design and evaluation. Outreach efforts and best practices amongst priority groups, such as rural communities, will be investigated and discussed.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Description: Required course for students residing in the University Housing Health Professions Residential College. Students learn about the campus and community resources, explore various health-related professions, are civically engaged, and participate in service projects. Cross-listed with KINES 250, may be taken once for credit.

Emphasis on data and analytic methods in healthcare and public health, quantitative reasoning, data integrity, data visualization, interpretation and use of results to make informed decisions. Topics include an introduction to dashboards using Tableau.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed at least 1 of the following:
  MATH153 - Statistical Reasoning (FM) (3)
  MATH254 - Statistical Methods (FM) (3)
  KINES301 - Statistics, Measurement and Evaluation Concepts (3)
  PSYC295 - Statistical Methods (3)
  SOC310 - Elementary Social Statistics (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Course Title: Data Analytics for Statewide Health Collaborative II
Description: Continue a designated DASH Lab project to propose actionable insights on healthcare and public health data problems. May be repeated twice for credit.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
HLTH471 - Data Analytics for Statewide Health Collaborative I (2)

Description: Presentation of selected health science topics under faculty direction.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of senior or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Advanced study of a specialized topic; design and completion of a project may be included in the study. The student works with a high degree of Independence to meet well-defined goals under the supervision of a member of the graduate faculty. Requires submission of a completed Application for Graduate Independent Study prior to the deadline specified in the academic calendar. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken. Either graded or pass/fail.

Course Title: Data Analytics for Statewide Health Collaborative I
Description: Participate in the Data Analytics for Statewide Health Collaborative (DASH Lab), a hands-on data immersive learning experience working on real healthcare and public health data problems. The first semester of a one-year sequence course. May be repeated once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Design and engage in a capstone project that synthesizes healthcare and/or public health concepts and addresses current health and wellness-related issues within various contexts.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Designed to provide students with professional experiences, regardless of their major. Students will develop their professional network alongside a mentor at a Treasure Valley employer. Time spent on site with employers and in a weekly class session. The class sessions are designed to unpack what the students are learning on the job, attend interactive workshops, engage with dynamic guest leaders from partner employers, and learn skills that translate directly to a professional setting. No more than 12 credits of Work U and/or internship may be applied towards graduation requirements.
Presentation of selected health science topics under faculty direction.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of senior or higher

Description: This course is designed to familiarize students with the prominent theories, issues, and topics in the field of health communication with a range of topics, including illness and health, historical and contemporary issues, patient and provider experiences, cultural differences in health, public awareness/prevention/intervention campaigns, and the role of media and relationships in health communication.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Provides the foundational skills needed to manipulate, analyze, and visualize health data. Covers the fundamentals of Excel, an introduction to database design principles, the importance of data integrity, standard language for managing and querying relational databases, and best practices in data visualization.

Course Title: Health Informatics and Data Management II
Description: Strategies for the use and exchange of health data and information. Focus on health data in research, privacy and security management practices and safeguards, data governance, extraction and reporting, interpretation and visualization, and current trends in technology.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
HLTH320 - Health Informatics and Data Management I (3)

Course Title: Prevention and Control of Infectious Disease
Description: Identify the main pathogens and groups of pathogens causing emerging and re-emerging infectious diseases. Describe epidemiology, biology, pathology, clinical manifestations and prevention measures. Develop a prevention and control plan for selected pathogens.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Pathophysiology provides the basic link between the sciences of anatomy, physiology, and biochemistry and their application to clinical practice. Emphasizes the dynamic aspects of disease processes in the human body. This includes disruption of normal physiology and a “system approach” to focus on risk factors, symptomatology, diagnostic tools, and treatment modalities. Cross-listed with PUBH300, can only be taken for credit once.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
BIOL227 - Human Anatomy and Physiology I (FN) (4)
BIOL228 - Human Anatomy and Physiology II (4)

Description: Provides an overview of health promotion during adolescence and emerging adulthood (approximately ages 11-23). Prepares students to assess the health and wellbeing of adolescents and emerging adults. Examines key priority areas of health and adolescent risk as identified by the Centers for Disease Control and health promotion programs and policies specific to the needs of this population.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Provides an overview of maternal and child health, issues, and trends. Preparation for assessing the health and wellbeing of expectant and new mothers, infants, and children. Examines key priority areas of maternal and child health as identified by the Centers for Disease Control and health promotion programs and policies specific to the needs of this population.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Social change and community work relies on cross-sector collaboration. This course investigates key tools and theories that empower and engage communities to address their own issues. Cross-listed with PUBH470, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Analyzes the relationship between the mental, emotional, and social dimensions of wellbeing. Covers evidence-based approaches to assessing and promoting these interrelated dimensions of wellbeing and empower individuals with the knowledge, skills, and strategies needed to enhance mental health, build resilience, and support the mental wellness of others. Cross-listed with PUBH356, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Course Title: Ethical and Legal Considerations in Patient Care
Description: Covers ethical principles and legal frameworks necessary to navigate the complex landscape of patient care and healthcare delivery. Examination of practical implications in providing patient-centered care while upholding professional standards and legal obligations. Cross-listed with PUBH315, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Description: Terminology, concepts, and forms used in both strategic planning and project management. Focuses on the similarities and differences between strategic planning (short and long term planning) and project planning (specific business activity that has a beginning and end).
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Introduces students to the field of environmental health, which is dedicated to protecting human health by preventing harmful exposures in the environment. Covers the major sources of environmental pollution and how contaminants in our air, water, soil and food can cause disease and illness in the population. Major regulations and other strategies for eliminating or reducing environmental exposures that put our health at risk are presented.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Evaluates delivery of health programs from Idaho’s major urban areas to its frontier and rural counties. Coverage of program delivery models from local public health districts, Idaho Department of Health and Welfare, non-profit organizations, and for profit organizations. Particular focus on the importance of collaboration between various agencies and organizations to promote community health. Cross-listed with PUBH445, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Focuses on the normal aging process and health concerns that affect an aging population. Strategies to maintain and enhance health for successful aging are emphasized.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: This course will introduce students to leadership theory. Students will then develop their own leadership skills through activities, discussions, and reflections. The workshop will take place over one weekend during the fall semester.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.
Group discussion of issues built around a specific theme/s. Because themes change from semester to semester, seminar may be repeated.

Group discussion of issues built around a specific leadership theme/s.  This course is open to Honors House Council and Honors Student Association leaders. Because themes change from semester to semester, seminar may be repeated. Recommended that the students have a successful application to Honors Leadership position.

Guides Honors sophomores through a process of personal exploration and reflection to identify or confirm why they are seeking a degree, what they want their future to look like, and how they can design the remainder of their university experience toward those aims. May be repeated for credit.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Upper-division students may earn credits in independent study, usually through directed reading or by completing a special project. Students may earn no more than 4 credits in a semester and no more than 6 credits during a single academic year, and no more than a total of 9 credits may be used to meet degree requirements or university graduation requirements. Before enrolling for independent study, a student must obtain the approval of the department chair, acting on the recommendation of the instructor who will be supervising the independent study. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken.
Trains Peer Mentors in applied leadership and mentoring. Because themes change from semester to semester, this course may be repeated.

Group discussion of issues built around a specific leadership theme/s.  This course is open to Honors House Council and Honors Student Association leaders. Because themes change from semester to semester, seminar may be repeated. Recommended that the students have a successful application to Honors Leadership position.
Group discussion of issues built around a specific theme/s. Because themes change from semester to semester, seminar may be repeated.

This course will introduce students to leadership theory. Students will then develop their own leadership skills through activities, discussions, and reflections. The workshop will take place over one weekend during the fall semester.

Implementation, administration, maintenance, and control of a comprehensive compensation program. Job analysis, job evaluation, pricing of jobs, supplemental benefits, incentive plans, performance appraisal, variable pay, and international compensation issues are included.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to College of Business and Economics Admission
Completed the following:
  HRM305 - Human Resource Management (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. No more than 12 internship credits may be used to meet degree requirements or university graduation requirements.

Introduction to people analytics, also known as workforce analytics or HR analytics. Learn how to interpret and analyze people data, using evidence-based HRM practices and analytical techniques that help solve challenges. Hands-on approach to learn about and apply human capital measurement and metrics, predictive analytic tools and methods, and other frequently used metrics to collect and analyze people data. Recommended: HRM305.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to College of Business and Economics Admission

Description: History, structure, policies, and operations of labor unions, the functioning of industrial relations activities within organizations, and important concepts and terminology in labor management relations. Contract administration is emphasized with a focus on the day-to-day relationships. International comparisons are made. Construction management majors need permission to enroll.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  BUS202 - The Legal Environment of Business (3)
  ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Declared or admitted to College of Business and Economics Admission, or Construction Management BS

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Overview and application of the major human resource management functions: selection and placement, compensation and benefits, training and development, employee and labor relations, health, safety, and security, and strategic management practices. Legal, motivational, international, merger and acquisition, and human resource information system issues are included.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of junior or higher

Description: Current trends in selection and training are covered. Includes measurement of individual differences for decision making in hiring, promoting, training, and dismissal; evaluation of HRM processes and systems; formal and informal training program design; and evaluation of training effectiveness.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to College of Business and Economics Admission
Completed the following:
  HRM305 - Human Resource Management (3)

Description: Designed to provide students with professional experiences, regardless of their major. Students will develop their professional network alongside a mentor at a Treasure Valley employer. Time spent on site with employers and in a weekly class session. The class sessions are designed to unpack what the students are learning on the job, attend interactive workshops, engage with dynamic guest leaders from partner employers, and learn skills that translate directly to a professional setting. No more than 12 credits of Work U and/or internship may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description:
To earn graduate credit you must have a 3.00 cumulative GPA and no more than 12 credits may be applied toward a graduate degree or second undergraduate degree. Some graduate programs, however, accept only 3 internships credits. Practicum/Internship cannot be repeated to improve a grade. Either graded or pass/fail.
Notes: An undergraduate internship is an entry level employment experience related to the discipline. The graduate intern already has an undergraduate degree and is expected to perform with a higher level of responsibility, decision-making authority, and accomplishment.

Upper-division students may earn credits in independent study, usually through directed reading or by completing a special project. Students may earn no more than 4 credits in a semester and no more than 6 credits during a single academic year, and no more than a total of 9 credits may be used to meet degree requirements or university graduation requirements. Before enrolling for independent study, a student must obtain the approval of the department chair, acting on the recommendation of the instructor who will be supervising the independent study. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken.

The general principles of employment and labor law and the effective application of these principles. Issues such as employment-at-will, employment discrimination, fair labor standards, organizing campaigns, and unfair labor practices are discussed. Construction management majors need permission to enroll.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  BUS202 - The Legal Environment of Business (3)
  ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Declared or admitted to College of Business and Economics Admission, or Construction Management BS

Description: Activities to explore ideas in the visual arts, performing arts, literature, philosophy, and music. Reflection on the human condition as it is revealed through the arts, literature, and philosophy. May be repeated for credit.

Activities to explore ideas in the visual arts, performing arts, literature, philosophy, and music. Reflection on the human condition as it is revealed through the arts, literature, and philosophy. May be repeated for credit.

An interdisciplinary exploration of human intellectual and creative heritage as expressed in literature, music, philosophy and/or the visual and performing arts. Emphasis on the intersection of liberal arts and critical thinking.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Execution of a substantial exercise that demonstrates the ability to successfully and independently carry out a professional activity similar to what is encountered in the professional workplace; archival of the results of the project is required according to standards approved by the Graduate College. May be repeated for credit. Pass/fail only.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: A broad-based selection of significant student work that is used to appraise student performance and professional development. A portfolio reflects the depth and breadth of a student’s educational growth since entering the graduate program. Portfolios may include, but not be limited to, classroom examinations, journals, writing samples, publishable scholarship, professional projects, annotated bibliographies, and artistic endeavors, Pass/fail only.

Explore academic and career goal-setting strategies, innovative thinking frameworks, the connection of theory to practice, academic culture, academic integrity, the vital nature of an academic support community, and the qualities of a reflective and adaptive learner.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Interdisciplinary Studies BA, or Interdisciplinary Studies BS

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Readings-based course that allows students to work with faculty to design their own course of study focused on the professional skills and knowledge they need to succeed in their chosen careers. Students will work with the instructor to develop a personalized reading list and assignment schedule that aligns with their career goals. Cross-listed with IPS392 and TEAM392, may be taken for a maximum of six credits.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of junior or higher
Co-requisites: Rule Not Selected

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: The conduct of topical research, assigned readings or literature review. The faculty advisor and the student prepare and sign an agreement describing the amount and type of work to be accomplished. May be repeated for credit. Either graded or pass/fail.

Students work directly with a faculty Learning Mentor to reflect upon their developed skills and apply them to their professional aspirations. As an experiential learning opportunity, practicum commonly includes working within an instructional or training context or an applied project. One credit equals 45 hours of on-site or remote field work. May be repeated for a maximum of 3 credits.
Complete and present an integrative capstone project and a culminating self-evaluation.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description:
To earn graduate credit you must have a 3.00 cumulative GPA and no more than 12 credits may be applied toward a graduate degree or second undergraduate degree. Some graduate programs, however, accept only 3 internships credits. Practicum/Internship cannot be repeated to improve a grade. Either graded or pass/fail.
Notes: An undergraduate internship is an entry level employment experience related to the discipline. The graduate intern already has an undergraduate degree and is expected to perform with a higher level of responsibility, decision-making authority, and accomplishment.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Advanced study of a specialized topic; design and completion of a project may be included in the study. The student works with a high degree of Independence to meet well-defined goals under the supervision of a member of the graduate faculty. Requires submission of a completed Application for Graduate Independent Study prior to the deadline specified in the academic calendar. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken. Either graded or pass/fail.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Independent research or creativity activity at the master’s level resulting in a thesis that must be defended at a final oral examination and archived in the university library. The thesis must be written in clear and effective English and presented in a format that conforms to the standards of the Graduate College. May be repeated for credit. Pass/fail only.

IEPATH exit requirement course. Demonstrate advanced proficiency in the written and spoken discourse of US English by means of a research paper, an expanded oral presentation on the topic of the paper, and a completion of IEPATH portfolio. Course includes an exit oral proficiency interview. May be repeated for credit one time.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: Emphasis on the development of advanced speaking skills to prepare for successful participation in graduate-level classes in the U.S. Focus on the development of presentation skills, integration of academic research and the expansion of active use of academic vocabulary. May not be applied to a graduate degree.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: Exploration of academic writing, discourse and argument. Emphasis on application of organizational patterns, research integration and strategies of writing for academic purposes. Students will write extensive research-based essays and responses in preparation for an American graduate program. May not be applied to a graduate degree.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Course Title: Advanced English Academic Reading and Vocabulary
Description: Close readings of academic material and novels, including analysis of literary devices, and abstract and concrete concepts. Students will evaluate sources for logic, accuracy and quality of scholarship as well as practice independent vocabulary acquisition and expand targeted academic vocabulary. May be repeated for credit one time.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Course Title: Intermediate English Academic Reading and Vocabulary I
Description: Emphasis on intensive and extensive reading of adapted fiction and nonfiction with a focus on vocabulary development. Addresses reading skills such as note-taking, skimming, scanning, inferring, and summarizing.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Further development of the formation of complex sentence structures with a focus on expression and accuracy. Emphasis on the accurate use of tense, voice, and dependent clauses to express ideas about texts and the opinions of others. Intensive study of high intermediate structures in a communicative context.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Course Title: Intermediate English Academic Reading and Vocabulary II
Description: Development of critical thinking through the reading and interpretation of authentic materials. Guided acquisition of academic vocabulary using a variety of decoding techniques and corpus linguistics.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: An intensive study of the formal written and spoken structures of English grammar with a focus on accurate expression. Development and application of a variety of advanced grammatical structures including in-depth analysis of morphology and rules through output in written and spoken communication. Addresses the subtleties of structures and exceptions.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Focuses on an inquiry-based research project. Development of a research question, collection evidence and data, process writing and presentation of research essay. Continued discussion of academic integrity with a focus on improving effective U.S. citation practices.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: Focus on extensive critical reading and analysis of academic topics in preparation for graduate studies. Exploration of rhetorical techniques and structures. Students will learn strategies to respond to academic texts and will expand targeted academic vocabulary. May not be applied to a graduate degree.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Emphasis on the development of public speaking skills through academic discussion, debate, presentations, and research. Guided acquisition of integrating academic vocabulary in public speaking.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: Introduction to and practical application of research methods appropriate for conducting research in various contexts. Investigation of a variety of research approaches and strategies. Students will design, conduct, report and evaluate research projects. May be repeated for up to six credits. May not be applied to a graduate degree.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Study and practice of the essay writing process with attention to thesis, clarity, organization, and cohesion. Students will demonstrate sentence variety through writing compound, complex, and compound-complex sentences.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: Emphasis on the development of advanced speaking skills in preparation for presentations conforming to U.S. university expectations. Expansion of active use of academic vocabulary. Students will prepare community-based research projects.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Emphasis on integration into U.S. university classroom culture, academic social protocols, and collaborative learning styles. Targets acquisition of academic vocabulary, and study strategies for reading college textbooks, academic articles and informational essays. Direct applications of strategies to the reading materials in IEPATH student's current university courses.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: Emphasis on the development of advanced critical listening and note-taking skills through longer academic lectures. Students will develop interview skills and conduct primary research to support their academic portfolios.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Intensive review of fundamentals of grammatical structures in a communicative context. Exploration of compound and complex sentence structures and correct usage of intermediate level grammatical verb tenses and structures. Focus on expression and accuracy.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Course Title: Intermediate English Critical Listening Skills I
Description: Introduction to academic presentations and short lectures. Students will apply various listening comprehension strategies and note-taking skills.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: Emphasis on enhancing research and project management skills. Conduct extensive research for writing projects and evaluate sources for logic, accuracy, and quality of scholarship. Use collaborative writing process for writing annotated bibliographies, literary analysis and research essays. May be repeated for credit one time. May not be applied to a graduate degree.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: Focus on citing sources, summarizing and paraphrasing, and other effective, ethical citation practices used in extensive research-based writing. Practice independent vocabulary acquisition and using sentence variety to produce more sophisticated essays and responses in preparation for a U.S. university classroom. May be repeated for credit one time.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Development of critical thinking and writing through analysis of sample essays and discussions of different rhetorical styles. Emphasis on essay process writing and accurate integration of research. Introduces U.S. techniques to citing sources. Students will practice using a variety of complex sentences and verb tenses.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Course Title: Intermediate English Critical Listening Skills II
Description: Focus on effective and clear note-taking skills through practice and exposure to a variety of spoken input. Students will develop listening strategies such as identifying verbal cues and analyzing logical arguments, effective persuasion, appropriate justification, and rebuttal.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Emphasis on the development of emergent fluency and accuracy in spoken English. Students will discuss a variety of topics with a focus on development and integration of academic vocabulary.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: Further development of advanced speaking skills to prepare for successful participation in graduate-level classes in the U.S. Continued focus on the development of presentation skills and the expansion of active use of academic vocabulary. May not be applied to a graduate degree.
Prerequisites: Admission to IEPATH program, IEP Placement scores

Description: Students in an IFITS supported cohort work on professional skills related to becoming a scholar, including oral, written, and presentation communication skills, effective teamwork, using one’s strengths to contribute to a collaborative project, and asking meaningful research questions. Each section of this course is dedicated to a different supported cohort program which will have its own specific learning outcomes in addition to the skill set listed above. Course may be repeated up to 6 semesters for credit.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Provides insight into research or creative work through inquiry, investigation, discovery, and application. There is a possibility of collaborating with graduate students who are performing graduate-level research. All research is supervised by a faculty member. May be repeated for credit. Either graded or pass/fail. It is recommended that the 0 credit option be offered as pass/fail.

Students in an IFITS supported cohort work on professional skills related to becoming a scholar, including oral, written, and presentation communication skills, effective teamwork, using one’s strengths to contribute to a collaborative project, and asking meaningful research questions. Each section of this course is dedicated to a different supported cohort program which will have its own specific learning outcomes in addition to the skill set listed above. Course may be repeated up to 6 semesters for credit.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Small group meetings for the exchange ideas, debate of issues, or presentation of research. Format, conduct, and purpose of seminars vary widely among disciplines. Either graded or pass/fail.
Design of experiments, analysis methods, and interpretation of results and conclusions as related to evidence based research in health.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS
Or admitted to the pre-Advanced Medical Imaging BS or pre-Radiologic Sciences BS degree plans
Completed at least 1 of the following:
  MATH153 - Statistical Reasoning (FM) (3)
  MATH254 - Statistical Methods (FM) (3)
  PSYC295 - Statistical Methods (3)
  POLS299 - Introduction to Political Research (3)
  SOC310 - Elementary Social Statistics (3)
  KINES301 - Statistical Methods in Health Sciences (3)

Or any introductory statistics course

Course Title: Preventative Care and Patient Advocacy in Imaging Sciences (FF)
Description: Analysis of preventative care measures provided through medical imaging procedures. Patient care, responsibilities, ethics, and policies required of healthcare providers.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS

Course Title: Study of Diseases in Imaging Sciences
Description: Examination of the disease processes demonstrated with imaging sciences related to pathogenesis, patient populations, treatment options and prognosis.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, Radiologic Sciences BS, or Radiologic Sciences Certificates Admission

Description: Process of legal change and health care practitioners' potential interactions with patients, law enforcement, and governmental agencies. Consent, liability, negligence, employment and licensure of professionals.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS
Or declared to the pre-Advanced Medical Imaging BS or pre-Radiologic Sciences BS

Description: Managerial application of information technology in medical imaging to include basis networking, PACS, RIS, HIS, DICOM, standards and information security.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS

Course Title: Civic Engagement, Ethics and Global Diversity
Description: Focused on guiding students to become influential leaders in thought and skill through discussion of civil engagement, ethics, diversity, and internationalization.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS

Course Title: Professionalism and Research in Imaging Sciences
Description: Introduction to empirical research, literary source analysis, leadership style efficacy and developing professional goals for patient advocacy.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS

Description: Public health concepts and practice. Topics include philosophy, purpose, history, organization, functions, tools, activities and results at national, state, and community levels.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS

Description: Analysis of the biological effects of ionizing radiation. Promotion and advocacy for patients, focused on dose and exposure reduction.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS

Course Title: Advanced Sectional Anatomy in Imaging Sciences
Description: Advanced level identification of anatomical structures on sectional images to include sagittal, coronal, and transverse body planes utilizing MRI and CT imaging.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS
Complete all of the following
  Complete 1 of the following
    Declared or admitted to Advanced Medical Imaging BS, Radiologic Sciences BS, or Radiologic Sciences Certificates Admission
    Or Pre-Radiologic Sciences BS or Pre-Advanced Medical Imaging BS

  Completed the following:
    AMI330 - Introduction to Sectional Anatomy (2)

Description: In depth analysis of factors affecting digital medical image acquisition processes, primarily emphasizing problem-solving, critical thinking, collaboration and reasoning. Equipment manufacturer analysis through vendor comparison.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS

Course Title: Human Resource Management in Health Care
Description: Overview and application of the major human resource management functions: selection and placement, compensation and benefits, training and development, employee and labor relations, health, safety, and security, and strategic management practices related to the health care industry. Legal, motivational, international, merger, and acquisition, and human resource information system issues are included.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS
Or declared to the pre-Advanced Medical Imaging BS degree plan or pre-Radiologic Sciences BS degree plan

Description: Provides an introduction to health information systems, current legislation impacting health informatics, privacy and security of healthcare records, and healthcare technology as related to Imaging Sciences.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Imaging Sciences BS, Advanced Medical Imaging BS, or Radiologic Sciences BS

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Covers how to take effective action in the global business environment through strategic frameworks that consider market choices, investment and ownership modes, management processes, sustainability, and the role of government and industry in strategically promoting economic development.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to International Business BBA
Completed the following:
  BUS334 - International Management (3)
  INTBUS230 - Go Global: You and the World Economy (3)

Must have a class standing of senior or higher

Description: This course will form the structure for the experiential learning portion of the Asia Biztech summer in Taiwan program. The heart of this course will be six intensive days of meetings, workshops, and visits with some of the leading business, government, academic, and cultural centers in Taiwan. Students will be able and expected to have in-depth conversations with these key figures which will help them get into the mindset for the intensive Chinese and internship portions of the program to follow.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
INTBUS388 - Asia Biztech: Doing Business in Asia-Pacific (3)

Description: The law and policy of international economic institutions (e.g., World Trade Organization, NAFTA), national government regulation and private law affecting international transactions in trade in goods, services, technology, and investments. Also selected issues in U.S. foreign/trade policy and ethical/social responsibility. Recommended completion of INTBUS 230. Cross-listed with POLS 445, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to College of Business and Economics Admission
Complete 1 of the following
  Must have a class standing of senior or higher
  Completed at least 1 of the following:
    POLS305 - Comparative Global Politics (3)
    POLS306 - International Relations: Actors, Interactions, and Methods (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internships with local and overseas companies who work in international business are available to INTBUS majors who meet internship requirements. Recommended admission to COBE, a cumulative GPA of 2.5; a business GPA of 3.0; a current resume submitted to the INTBUS office; and a recommendation of faculty advisor.

Designed to provide students with professional experiences, regardless of their major. Students will develop their professional network alongside a mentor at a Treasure Valley employer. Time spent on site with employers and in a weekly class session. The class sessions are designed to unpack what the students are learning on the job, attend interactive workshops, engage with dynamic guest leaders from partner employers, and learn skills that translate directly to a professional setting. No more than 12 credits of Work U and/or internship may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Course Title: Asia Biztech: Doing Business in Asia-Pacific
Description: Introduces students to the basics of doing business in the Indo-Pacific region. Course will include an overview of the history, politics, economies, technological development, and cultures of the various countries within the region and how they interact both regionally and globally, and explores their influence on how business is conducted. Course includes online meetings with representatives from various regional actors.
The course uses a computer-simulated business game to provide teams of students the opportunity to learn how firms from Japan, the U.S., and Germany compete in a global economy.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to College of Business and Economics Admission
Completed the following:
  INTBUS230 - Go Global: You and the World Economy (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Advanced study of a specialized topic; design and completion of a project may be included in the study. The student works with a high degree of Independence to meet well-defined goals under the supervision of a member of the graduate faculty. Requires submission of a completed Application for Graduate Independent Study prior to the deadline specified in the academic calendar. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken. Either graded or pass/fail.

Defines both culture and communication broadly and explores their influence on the conduct of business in the international arena. Includes linkages between culture and communication in general; and specifically, the impact of dimensions such as education, language, historical experience, social structure, and diplomatic relations on bilateral and international trade.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to College of Business and Economics Admission

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Upper-division students may earn credits in independent study, usually through directed reading or by completing a special project. Students may earn no more than 4 credits in a semester and no more than 6 credits during a single academic year, and no more than a total of 9 credits may be used to meet degree requirements or university graduation requirements. Before enrolling for independent study, a student must obtain the approval of the department chair, acting on the recommendation of the instructor who will be supervising the independent study. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken.

Course Title: Go Global: You and the World Economy
Description: Students will gain an intermediate level of understanding of international trade and business practices, as well as the historical influences of culture and ethics within the context of the global business environment. This course will promote greater awareness of the world as a community in which we all participate and are responsible.

Focusing on exporting and importing, this course offers practical experience in international trade. Specifically, the course will cover payment and financial procedures, export procedures and documents, shipment methods, counter trade, and resources available for importers and exporters.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to College of Business and Economics Admission
Completed the following:
  INTBUS230 - Go Global: You and the World Economy (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Explore the eight dimensions of wellness and their connections, from support networks and stress management to physical and financial wellness. Evaluate personal well-being, enhance self-awareness, and set goals to create a holistic personal growth and wellness plan.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Must have a class standing of junior or higher
Declared or admitted to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies Online BA
or permission of instructor
Co-requisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
  BAS305 - Introduction to the Bachelor of Applied Science (2)
  IPS305 - Introduction to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies (2)

Must have a class standing of upper-division
or permission of instructor

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Readings-based course that allows students to work with faculty to design their own course of study focused on the professional skills and knowledge they need to succeed in their chosen careers. Students will work with the instructor to develop a personalized reading list and assignment schedule that aligns with their career goals. Cross-listed with IDS392 and TEAM392, may be taken for a maximum of six credits.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of junior or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: A supervised on-site or remote experiential learning opportunity. Deepen critical knowledge areas, enhance professional skills, and reflect on applied work experiences and academic and professional goals. Internships can be in any field or area of interest and require the approval of the Internship Coordinator. One credit equals 45 hours of on-site or remote field work. May be repeated up to a maximum of 9 credits.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examine an issue from multiple perspectives and learn to broadly and accurately grasp other viewpoints, to identify the differences between them, to discover the common ground they share, and to evaluate their soundness.
Co-requisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
  IPS305 - Introduction to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies (2)
  BAS305 - Introduction to the Bachelor of Applied Science (2)

Must have a class standing of upper-division
or permission of instructor.

Description: Gain tools and frameworks to harness the power of emotional intelligence, enhancing self-awareness, communication, and relationship-building skills.

Course Title: Community Impact Seminar: Activate Your Impact
Description: Develop the skills to create a positive impact in the community by transforming unique experiences and strengths into meaningful contributions.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Explore and apply the elements of a creative and collaborative mindset to generate original and adaptive solutions to challenging problems. Review and practice the stages of the creative process, from risk to revision, and set individual goals to develop more deliberate and productive creative collaborations.
Co-requisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
  BAS305 - Introduction to the Bachelor of Applied Science (2)
  IPS305 - Introduction to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies (2)

Must have a class standing of upper-division
or permission of instructor

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Introduces the historical and modern phenomenon of Globalization. Various themes in globalization will be studied, including: economics, national powers, history, trade, environment, religion, and education. Each module will introduce particular aspects of globalization.
Co-requisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
  BAS305 - Introduction to the Bachelor of Applied Science (2)
  IPS305 - Introduction to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies (2)

Must have a class standing of upper-division
or permission of instructor

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Complete and present an integrative capstone project and a culminating self-evaluation.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Develops a foundation of concepts that support the project management process groups required for successful implementation and completion of a project. Principles and applied techniques of effective planning, communication, risk, schedule, and cost management are major themes discussed in this course.
Co-requisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
  BAS305 - Introduction to the Bachelor of Applied Science (2)
  IPS305 - Introduction to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies (2)

Must have a class standing of upper-division
or permission of instructor

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Explore the theory and practice of integrative thinking and the skills and strategies necessary to develop an integrative mindset, to integrate personal histories and experiences with new ideas, and to become a reflective and adaptive learner.
Co-requisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
  BAS305 - Introduction to the Bachelor of Applied Science (2)
  IPS305 - Introduction to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies (2)

Must have a class standing of upper-division
or permission of instructor.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Discover and use design thinking principles and frameworks to craft a work life that is meaningful, fulfilling, and aligned with your professional values and goals.
Co-requisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
  IPS305 - Introduction to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies (2)
  BAS305 - Introduction to the Bachelor of Applied Science (2)

Must have a class standing of upper-division
or permission of instructor.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Question a practical problem holistically to identify its conditions and costs, to discover new connections and relationships, and ultimately, to recognize, understand, and clearly articulate its breadth and complexity.
Co-requisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
  IPS305 - Introduction to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies (2)
  BAS305 - Introduction to the Bachelor of Applied Science (2)

Must have a class standing of upper-division
or permission of instructor.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines universal ethics principles and standards practiced across various disciplines. Exploration of personal and professional conduct and social responsibility in the light of existing ethical, moral and social values across disciplines will also be discussed. Designed to enable students to form individual positions on ethical conduct and social responsibility, this course both identifies and applies ethical principles to real world situations.
Co-requisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
  BAS305 - Introduction to the Bachelor of Applied Science (2)
  IPS305 - Introduction to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies (2)

Must have a class standing of upper-division
or permission of instructor

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Designed for individuals balancing full-time or part-time work, this program integrates professional experiences with readings and assignments focused on workplace and academic topics. It emphasizes experiential learning, creating a bridge between theory and practice. Through active experimentation and weekly reflections, the workplace serves as a dynamic environment for testing ideas, observing outcomes, and applying theoretical concepts to real-world situations. Cross-listed with TEAM391, may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Explore the dynamics of community development, social impact, and solution-driven community collaborations. Apply community-based learning principles, theories, and practices to create a meaningful partnership and community-based or service-oriented project with a local organization, nonprofit, or community group.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Must have a class standing of upper-division
or permission of instructor.

Description: Gain tools and insights to explore and strengthen a personal approach to leadership, fostering self-awareness, strategic thinking, and effective decision-making.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Explore academic and career goal-setting strategies, innovative thinking frameworks, the connection of theory to practice, academic culture, academic integrity, the vital nature of an academic support community, and the qualities of a reflective and adaptive learner.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Interdisciplinary Professional Studies Online BA, or Interdisciplinary Professional Studies BA

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Introduces and analyzes effective leadership styles. Leadership practices and models are applied to case studies. Through various forms of reading, writing, presentations, video and/or multi-media, students will apply theories to assess their own leadership style and identify styles of popular companies/people. Completion of LEAD 325 is recommended.

Description: Discuss and apply prior learning frameworks and methods for presenting experiences outside of a traditional classroom as verifiable college-level learning. Create a Prior Learning Portfolio, which includes an educational narrative, a skills-based prior learning resume, and relevant supporting documentation, and earn academic credit by taking the program-prepared challenge exams for specific courses.

Course Title: Community Impact Seminar: Community Interconnection and Collaboration
Description: Explores interactions within various community systems, providing essential skills to navigate, engage with, and influence these structures effectively.

Description: Dedicates a semester of coursework to a discrete project. Individually-designed immersive learning experiences encourage creative responses to tangible challenges through the development of creative/research projects. With modeling and mentoring, students work collaboratively and cross-disciplinarily, develop projects from start to finish, present their results, and build relationships with community partners.

Study of information technology resources that support decision making in organizations. Enterprise systems, databases, networks, and other technologies that support the collection, organization, and analysis of data are discussed. Skills necessary to collect, process, analyze, and present business intelligence are practiced through hands-on project experience. Ethical, legal, and behavioral issues of conducting business intelligence considered throughout.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Complete 1 of the following
  Completed the following:
    ITM105 - Spreadsheet Topics (2)

  Or successful completion of the COBE Computer Placement Exam for ITM 105.

Complete 1 of the following
  Business Majors
    Completed the following:
      BUSCOM201 - Business Communication (3)

  Business and Economic Analytics Majors
    Completed the following:
      ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

  Non-business majors
    Completed at least 1 of the following:

      WRITE212 - Introduction to Technical Communication (3)
Department: Information Technology and Supply Chain Management (ITSCM)

Description: Introduction to Programming with C# and object-oriented design principles. Includes essential programming concepts of data types, decision-making, iteration, encapsulation, inheritance, error handling, testing, and documentation.

Complete all of the following
Completed at least 1 of the following:

Description: An introduction to the essentials of cloud computing. Hands-on exercises provide a foundation in infrastructure, platform, and software as a service concepts including storage, computing, networking, identity and access management, content delivery and management.

Department: Information Technology and Supply Chain Management (ITSCM)

Course Title: Introduction to IT and Analytics Careers
Description: Introduction to a variety of career paths in information technology, such as data, analytics, infrastructure, development, security, and project management, through guest lectures from industry experts and hands-on activities. Preparation for internship and career opportunities in IT will be discussed.

Completed the following:

Completed the following:

Students will learn rhetorical tools for translating scientific findings and policy for a wider public. Cross-listed with HCS375, may be taken once for credit.

Portfolios may include, but not be limited to, classroom examinations, journals, writing samples, publishable scholarship, professional projects, annotated bibliographies, and artistic endeavors, Pass/fail only.

Complete 1 of the following
Must have a class standing of junior or higher
or permission of instructor

Completed the following:

Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to K-12 Physical Education and Health BS

Description: Focus on the acquisition of motor skills to enhance motor performance along with a basic understanding how decisions are made and executed from sensory systems, existing knowledge, and previous movement experiences. In depth examination of effective learning strategies including demonstrations, verbal cueing, attentional focus, designing and organizing practice schedules, as well as correcting errors. Meet with an advisor to determine if the corresponding lab, KINES 376, is required.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed at least 1 of the following:
  KINES270 - Applied Anatomy (3)
  KINES303 - Neuroanatomy and Physiology (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher
