Description: Focus on the individual behaviors and mental processes that contribute to happiness through a scientific lens. Subjects include, and are not limited to: empathy, humor, kindness, forgiveness, gratitude, compassion, and mindfulness. An emphasis is placed on the application of this science through the development of a personal happiness practice.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Second in a series of four created to provide direct touch points with students to facilitate academic preparedness, career exploration, establish post graduate trajectories, and develop resources for transitioning post college. With the support of faculty/staff, focus on developing academic plans that align with their anticipated post graduate goals. Identify specific post graduate trajectories, develop academic plans that support those trajectories, and begin to develop a skills narrative that represents their development thus far in college.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC111 - Professional Development: Freshman (1)

Description: Foundation for understanding the issues, principles, and models involved in the study of mental processes. Topics range from classic cognitive psychology to more current neuroscience and artificial intelligence. Applications are emphasized.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC321 - Research Methods (4)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: A detailed account of the history of psychology encompassing the philosophical antecedents of modern psychology as well as the influential pioneers. Topics include history of psychology as a field of scientific inquiry, overview of development of schools of thought, prominent figures and key theories.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:

Completed the following:

Description: Independent study is an opportunity to earn academic credit outside of the established curriculum. It assumes the confluence of two streams of interest that of a student and that of a professor. Thus, enrollment is contingent on a voluntary commitment to the project by both parties. Course may be repeated for a maximum of 9 credits. Recommended psychology major, have a cumulative GPA above 3.0, completion of PSYC 321 and upper-division standing.

This course is designed to orient the prospective psychology major to the field of psychology and to inform the student about academic requirements, expectations, opportunities, career options and limitations.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Description: An individual research project in psychology selected by student. Proposal must be approved by instructor before enrolling. Recommended projects are those which will contribute to the body of psychological knowledge or will apply psychological principles to practical problems. Recommended for psychology students planning on graduate school. Course may be taken for a maximum of 3 credits. Recommended completion of PSYC 101, PSYC 321, and upper-division standing.

Utilize skills learned in PSYC410 and PSYC411 by serving as Psychology Peer Advisors. Assist psychology majors and minors with class scheduling, planning their degree, exploring minors and certificates, and answering academic-related questions.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: The conduct of topical research, assigned readings or literature review. The faculty advisor and the student prepare and sign an agreement describing the amount and type of work to be accomplished. Either graded or pass/fail.
Fundamental concepts of learning, with emphasis on classical conditioning, operant conditioning, and observational learning. Human applications of animal learning principles are stressed.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC321 - Research Methods (4)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Introduces fundamental theories, concepts, methods, issues, and psychology of organizational and employee effectiveness. Topics include employee selection, job analysis, criterion development, predictors of job performance, work teams, leadership, motivation, job attitudes, stress and well-being, and organizational development.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC321 - Research Methods (4)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: First in a series of four created to provide direct touch points with students to facilitate academic preparedness, career exploration, establish post graduate trajectories, and develop resources for transitioning post college. With the support of faculty/staff, focus on navigating the social, academic, and logistical challenges associated with college. Exploration of short and long term academic related goals. Specifically, academic and work force related post graduate options and outline experiences to prepare for those options.

A detailed account of the information and skills necessary to serve as an academic advisor as an undergraduate student. Topics include Boise State University’s undergraduate degree requirements, Psychology BS degree requirements, an overview of academic and personal support resources available to students, FERPA training, and the Department of Psychological Science’s expectations for undergraduate students serving as academic advisors. Opportunities to shadow current students serving as academic advisors for the Department of Psychological Science will also be provided.

Focuses on human and social problems in a systemic context. Primary prevention and community empowerment strategies employed are emphasized for individual, community, and social benefit. A course in research methods or statistics is recommended but not required.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Provides insight into research or creative work through inquiry, investigation, discovery, and application. There is a possibility of collaborating with graduate students who are performing graduate-level research. All research is supervised by a faculty member. May be repeated for credit. Either graded or pass/fail. It is recommended that the 0 credit option be offered as pass/fail.

Focuses on statistical methods for practical data analysis, including parametric and non-parametric analyses, ANOVA, multiple and logistic regression, generalized linear models, and dimension reduction methods using R to examine and understand human behavior. Students will conduct a research project designed in partnership with a professional stakeholder that delivers actionable outcomes. Cross-listed with ANTH485,  DATA-R485, and SOC485, may be taken for credit once.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed the following:
  ITM430 - Predictive Analytics (3)
  ITM340 - Big Data and Web Analytics (3)

Completed the following:
  DATA-R322 - Principles of Data Science (3)

Description: An undergraduate student assists on a research project, supervised by a member of the psychology faculty. Enrollment is contingent on a voluntary commitment to a research project by both parties (faculty and student). Course may be repeated for a maximum of 9 credits. Recommended psychology major, cumulative GPA above 3.00 and upper-division standing.
The application of scientific methodology to the study of behavior. Design of experiments, methods of analysis, and interpretation of data; reporting of behavioral research.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)
  PSYC120 - Introduction to the Psychology Major (2)
  PSYC295 - Statistical Methods (3)

Must have a class standing of junior or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: A seminar is a small class that examines a particular topic. Seminars are typically discussion oriented and are most commonly offered at the junior, senior, or graduate level.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description:
To earn graduate credit you must have a 3.00 cumulative GPA and no more than 12 credits may be applied toward a graduate degree or second undergraduate degree. Some graduate programs, however, accept only 3 internships credits. Practicum/Internship cannot be repeated to improve a grade. Either graded or pass/fail.
Notes: An undergraduate internship is an entry level employment experience related to the discipline. The graduate intern already has an undergraduate degree and is expected to perform with a higher level of responsibility, decision-making authority, and accomplishment.

Principles that have emerged from the experimental analysis of behavior will be examined. The principles include, but are not limited to, operant and classical conditioning. The course will deal with applications of these principles to the understanding and change of phobias, obesity, smoking, alcoholism, aberrant sexual behavior, and similar problems.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Description: Designed for psychology majors, the course emphasizes theories of human development including psychodynamic, behavioral, social-learning, and cognitive. Contemporary views of genetic and environmental contributions will be examined. Research designs appropriate to developmental issues will be explored. The emphasis will be on development from the prenatal period to adolescence.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Advanced study of a specialized topic; design and completion of a project may be included in the study. The student works with a high degree of Independence to meet well-defined goals under the supervision of a member of the graduate faculty. Requires submission of a completed Application for Graduate Independent Study prior to the deadline specified in the academic calendar. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken. Either graded or pass/fail.

Controversial issues and social problems are addressed. Students analyze how different areas of psychology contribute to the understanding of contemporary problems making psychological theory and research relevant and understandable to community agencies/groups.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC321 - Research Methods (4)

Must have a class standing of senior or higher

Description: The study of individual sexuality as well as the dynamics of close relationships from a variety of psychological perspectives. Topics covered include sexuality development, sexual behavior, initial attraction, dating patterns, long-term relationships, familial relationships, intimacy and communication, domestic violence, and relationship development.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Description: An overview of human sexuality emphasizing both physiological and psychological aspects of sexuality. Topics include sexual anatomy and physiology, sexual response cycle, childbirth, contraception, sexual dysfunction, sex role development, and sexual deviation. Cross-cultural values will be examined and a values clarification unit will be included.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.
Advanced topics in univariate statistics (for example, repeated measures designs) and multivariate techniques such as discriminant analysis, factor analysis, and principal component analysis.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC321 - Research Methods (4)

or equivalent

Description: Examines both typical and atypical development across the lifespan using an ecological systems perspective. Topics include the mutual influences and contexts of biology, personality, cognitions, social relationships and culture on a variety of age-related issues.

Serve as teaching assistant for PSYC 101. Experience may include attending lectures, holding office hours, tutoring students, grading papers, supervising review sessions, guest lecturing, and/or other duties relevant to the course. Recommended PSYC 101, upper-division standing, and a cumulative GPA above 3.00.
Theory and nature of psychological measurement together with a survey of types of psychological tests currently used.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC321 - Research Methods (4)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: The primary focus is the individual; the unit of analysis, the interpersonal behavior event. A study of individual motives, emotions, attitudes, and cognition with reference to interactions with other human beings. SOC 101 and a course in statistics or research design are strongly recommended. Cross-listed with SOC 431, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed at least 1 of the following:
  PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)
  SOC101 - How Society Really Works: An Introduction to Sociology (FS) (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: A descriptive approach to the study of the etiology, development, and dynamics of behavioral disorders, together with a review of current preventive and remedial practices.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Review of cultural similarity and differences in such areas as child development, gender roles, social behavior, language and communication, and mental illness. Focus on psychological theory and research relevant to explaining how cultural factors influence human behavior and thought.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Description: Provides advanced coverage of topics in the instructor's area of expertise, with particular focus on the application of psychological principles to address contemporary social problems. May be repeated for a maximum of nine credits.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC321 - Research Methods (4)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: The psychological processes underlying human development of eating behaviors and the adoption of both healthy and unhealthy cognitions and behaviors concerning food, eating, and body image. Issues addressed include: food choice, food preferences, eating motivation, cultural influences, weight regulation, body image, dieting, obesity, eating disorders, and treatment.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Research conducted by a graduate student under the supervision of a member of the graduate faculty. Requires the clear statement of a hypothesis or proposition, a review of the relevant literature, analysis and synthesis of data or scholarly evidence, and the inference of conclusions. The results must be stated in a report written in clear and effective English. Requires submission of an Application for Directed Research prior to the deadline specified in the academic calendar. Either graded or pass/fail.

Consideration of neuroscience with particular emphasis on current approaches and applications relating to human brain research. The goal is to illuminate the complex interaction shared by physiological/biological and mental functions and processes. The objective is to illustrate the dynamic role of neuroscience in transforming conventional ideology of brain processes and function.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  BIOL107 - Introduction to Human Biology (FN) (4)
  BIOL227 - Human Anatomy and Physiology I (FN) (4)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Investigation of mental processes and behavior through the lens of the scientific method. This survey course draws from topics within the American Psychological Association's five pillars of psychology: Pillar 1 Biological (Neuroscience, Sensation, Consciousness, Motivation); Pillar 2 Cognitive (Cognition, Memory, Perception); Pillar 3 Development (Learning, Life Span Development, Language); Pillar 4 Social and Personality (Social, Personality, Intelligence, Emotion, Multicultural, Gender); and Pillar 5 Mental and Physical Health (Abnormal, Health, Therapies).
A study of the major contemporary theories and concepts of personality, with special emphasis on psychoanalytic, humanistic, and behavioral approaches.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  PSYC295 - Statistical Methods (3)
  MATH254 - Statistical Methods (FM) (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Hands-on advising training course. Students will shadow current advisors and begin serving as psychology advisors in training.
Theory and nature of psychological measurement together with a survey of types of psychological tests currently used.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC321 - Research Methods (4)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Fourth in a series of four created to provide direct touch points with students to facilitate academic preparedness, career exploration, establish post graduate trajectories, and develop resources for transitioning post college. With the support of faculty/staff, finalize resources for transitioning post college. Specifically resumes (workforce) and curriculum vitae (graduate school), write personal statements, identify and engage/apply for post college opportunities, and practice interview skills.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC333 - Professional Development: Junior (1)

Description: Explores attitudes toward human diversity and includes the acquisition of skills necessary to work sensitively with individuals and groups who are subjected to prejudice and discrimination based on race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, socioeconomic status. Topics include experiences of people of oppressed groups and sociohistorical roots of biases.

This course focuses on how biological, psychological, cultural, and social factors affect health and illness. It evaluates the best ways to promote healthy living and prevent disease and how people react psychologically when they are diagnosed with an illness or asked to make lifestyle changes. It also covers the influence of stress, coping, personality, culture, and family on health.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  PSYC295 - Statistical Methods (3)
  MATH254 - Statistical Methods (FM) (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Serve as teaching assistant for one psychology course. Experience may include attending lectures, holding office hours, tutoring students, grading papers, supervising review sessions, guest lecturing, and/or other duties relevant to teaching the course. Course may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits. Recommended upper-division standing and a cumulative GPA above 3.00.

Examines gender issues from a psychological perspective, including scientific literature and psychological theories on these issues. Topics, among others, include work and family issues, biological vs. psychosocial influences on behavior, and gender roles.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Description: A survey of the basic concepts in the psychology of perception. Processes are stressed, although coverage of receptor structure and neural pathways is included.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Designed to provide students with professional experiences, regardless of their major. Students will develop their professional network alongside a mentor at a Treasure Valley employer. Time spent on site with employers and in a weekly class session. The class sessions are designed to unpack what the students are learning on the job, attend interactive workshops, engage with dynamic guest leaders from partner employers, and learn skills that translate directly to a professional setting. No more than 12 credits of Work U and/or internship may be applied towards graduation requirements.

The course provides an overview of research in the field of psychology and the law, and documents how psycholegal research relates to pressing issues facing the judicial system. A partial list of topics includes: eyewitness testimony, jury deliberations, criminal behavior, evidence, and the structure and function of the legal system. A course in statistics or research design is strongly recommended.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Research and theories on child development in the context of family interactions and influences. Examine cultural similarities and differences in parental values and beliefs about child rearing, socialization practices, gender roles in families, and the adolescent struggle for independence from family.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Serve as Psychology Peer Advisors. Duties include but are not limited to helping psychology majors and minors with class scheduling, planning their degree, exploring minors and certificates, answering academic-related questions, and helping mentor the incoming cohort of students enrolled in PSYC410 and PSYC411.
Advanced topics in univariate statistics (for example, repeated measures designs) and multivariate techniques such as discriminant analysis, factor analysis, and principal component analysis.

Completed the following:
  PSYC321 - Research Methods (4)

Description: An introduction to the core concepts of data science including: predictive modeling using machine learning and data mining; data gathering, extraction and cleaning; and exploratory data analysis. Emphasizes practical skills for liberal arts students to examine questions of human behavior using large and complex data sets. Cross-listed with ANTH322, DATA-R322, and SOC322, may be taken for credit once.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  CS133 - Foundations of Data Science (3)

Must take a statistics course
Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: An introduction to aging from a psychological perspective, exploring the increasing prevalence of older adults in society and the growing focus on their experiences. Topics include age-related differences in learning, memory, perception, and intellectual abilities; physiological, cognitive, sensory, personality, and interpersonal changes; major theories and stereotypes about aging; cognitive disorders associated with aging; and personal transitions in later life, including relationships, independence, and end-of-life considerations.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: A seminar is a small class that examines a particular topic. Seminars are typically discussion oriented and are most commonly offered at the junior, senior, or graduate level.

Designed for psychology majors, the course emphasizes theories of human development including psychodynamic, behavioral, social-learning, and cognitive. Includes contemporary views of genetics, the environmental, and research designs appropriate to developmental issues.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Third in a series of four created to provide direct touch points with students to facilitate academic preparedness, career exploration, establish post graduate trajectories, and develop resources for transitioning post college. With the support of faculty/staff, focus on developing the relationships and experiences that will empower them to make transitions post college. Specifically, development of both academic and workforce post graduate plans, identifying specific programs for graduate work and workforce related options.
Prerequisites:

PSYC222 - Professional Development: Sophomore (1)

Description: Statistical concepts and methods commonly used in treatment of data in the social sciences. Topics covered will include: measures of central tendency and of variability, correlation measures, probability, and analysis of variance.

Completed the following:
PSYC101 - Introduction to Psychology (FS) (3)

Description: Introduces and applies concepts and empirical methods of network analysis in a field-based project. Social networks influence learning, economic behavior, and adoption of new products and organizational innovations. Cross-listed with ANTH420, DATA-R420 and SOC420, may be taken for credit once.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher
And take a statistics course

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Background, objectives, scope, methods, and timeline of the dissertation research. Considerable autonomy is granted to the academic unit in the design, administration, and evaluation, and approval of the dissertation proposal. Pass/fail only.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or both (alt yr)
Description: Examines implications of information technology for policymaking and policy analysis as well as the management of knowledge and information in and between organizations.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: The conduct of topical research, assigned readings or literature review. The faculty advisor and the student prepare and sign an agreement describing the amount and type of work to be accomplished. Either graded or pass/fail.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines the public policy process including stages, types, and the roles public servants play.

Course Title: Public Land and Resource Policy and Administration
Description: Examines the major issues, actors, and policies affecting the public lands and resources of the United States. Special attention is paid to the processes, institutions, and organizations that influence how public land policy and resource policy is made.
Explores epistemological and normative issues involved in social science and public policy research.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Public Policy and Administration PhD

Description: Considers water resource policy, management, and politics in the US with attention to the clean Water Act, the Endangered Species Act, water allocation, public trust doctrines, and current water resource issues.

Examines processes by which policy actors communicate information about the environment, natural resources, and how they affect decision-making and behavior at both individual and institutional-levels.

Course Title: Selected Topics: Public Policy and Policy Analysis
Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Public Policy and Policy Analysis. May be repeated for credit.
Explores advanced application of policy theory to local, regional, state, national, comparative policy questions.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to Public Policy and Administration PhD
Completed the following:
  PUBADM601 - Philosophy of Social Inquiry (3)
  PUBADM603 - Theories of Public Policy (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Independent research at the doctoral level resulting in a dissertation that must be defended as a final oral examination and archived in the university library and with UMI. The dissertation must be written in clear and effective English and presented in a format that conforms to the standards of the Graduate College. Pass/fail only.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description:
To earn graduate credit you must have a 3.00 cumulative GPA and no more than 12 credits may be applied toward a graduate degree or second undergraduate degree. Some graduate programs, however, accept only 3 internships credits. Practicum/Internship cannot be repeated to improve a grade. Either graded or pass/fail.
Notes: An undergraduate internship is an entry level employment experience related to the discipline. The graduate intern already has an undergraduate degree and is expected to perform with a higher level of responsibility, decision-making authority, and accomplishment.
Introduces policy analysis, policy tools, and factors shaping the utilization of policy analysis. A significant portion of the course is spent in learning and applying analytical techniques.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
PUBADM501 - Public Policy Process (3)

Course Title: Security Regulation and Policy for Nuclear, Radiation and Cyber-Related Risk
Description: This regulation and policy course examines nuclear-radiation security, including cyber-nuclear risk, with an emphasis on the civilian sector. Topics will include: historical developments and relationships across nuclear security, safety and safeguards; national and international legal frameworks; organizations; transport and import/export; cooperation; culture and management.

Examines past, existing, and best practices for environmental management. Using a case study approach from the perspective of public administration and management, this class explores what management tools are used, and their level of success.

Course Title: How to Plan a Career in Public Service
Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines key skills for public servants that are marketable to employers, and career paths that include employment in public, private, and non-profit organizations.

Course Title: Contemporary Issues in Natural Resource and Environmental Policy and Administration
Description: Examines current and topical issues and controversies in natural resource and environmental policy from the perspective of public policy and public administration.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Advanced study of a specialized topic; design and completion of a project may be included in the study. The student works with a high degree of Independence to meet well-defined goals under the supervision of a member of the graduate faculty. Requires submission of a completed Application for Graduate Independent Study prior to the deadline specified in the academic calendar. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken. Either graded or pass/fail.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: A broad-based selection of significant student work that is used to appraise student performance and professional development. A portfolio reflects the depth and breadth of a student’s educational growth since entering the graduate program. Portfolios may include, but not be limited to, classroom examinations, journals, writing samples, publishable scholarship, professional projects, annotated bibliographies, and artistic endeavors, Pass/fail only.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines the way in which organizations make an assessment of, control, and transfer risk.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: An early assessment of a student’s potential to complete a doctoral program satisfactorily. Considerable autonomy is granted to the academic unit in the design, administration, and evaluation of the preliminary examination. Pass/fail only.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Provides an introduction to ethical challenges faced by public servants, including legal responsibilities.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines key issues in public financial management, including basic government accounting and regulations governing public spending.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Course Title: Seminar in State and Local Government Policy and Administration
Description: Examines current issues in state and local governance, with some particular attention paid to Western U.S. and state of Idaho issues and policies.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Public Policy and Administration PhD

Description: This course addresses such knowledge and skills for managers and leaders in public organizations as: personal assessment; leading and managing others; aspects of self and others which underlie behavior; managing stress and time; decision making; public participation; working with elected and appointed public officials; working with the media; solving problems; communicating supportively and assertively; appropriately using power and influence; understanding motivational processes; managing conflicts; empowering and delegating; and building teams.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or both (alt yr)
Description: Contributions of economic analysis to the justification, design, and implementation of economic policy, especially as it relates to the market economy and the benefits and costs associated with government intervention.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Independent research or creativity activity at the master’s level resulting in a thesis that must be defended at a final oral examination and archived in the university library. The thesis must be written in clear and effective English and presented in a format that conforms to the standards of the Graduate College. Pass/fail only.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Research conducted by a graduate student under the supervision of a member of the graduate faculty. Requires the clear statement of a hypothesis or proposition, a review of the relevant literature, analysis and synthesis of data or scholarly evidence, and the inference of conclusions. The results must be stated in a report written in clear and effective English. Requires submission of an Application for Directed Research prior to the deadline specified in the academic calendar. Either graded or pass/fail.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Introduction to techniques used to assess the potential impacts of policy choices.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Taken when the doctoral student is in Regular Status and has completed a significant number of course credits applicable to the degree requirements. Considerable autonomy is granted to the academic unit in the design, administration, and evaluation of the comprehensive examination. Pass/fail only.

Course Title: Environmental and Regulatory Policy and Administration
Description: Examines aspects of environmental regulatory politics and policy. Topics examined include the politics of regulation, pollution and energy policy, and intergovernmental environmental management.
Examines the role of science and scientists in the formation of U.S. environmental policy making. Special attention is given to the tension between elite and democratic forms of decision making.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Provides an introduction to ethical challenges faced by public servants, including legal responsibilities.
Students will explore the skills and techniques associated with successful grant writing and will prepare a grant proposal.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Explores issues related to leadership, mentoring and training employees, and working with others.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Considers the theories and practices of organization behavior and management in public and nonprofit organizations.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines the process by which decisions are in made in legislative bodies, including parliamentary process and budgetary allocations.

Course Title: How to Plan a Career in Public Service
Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines key skills for public servants that are marketable to employers, and career paths that include employment in public, private, and non-profit organizations.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Course examines Indigenous models of environmental governance and how Indigenous thought and initiatives offer insight into mainstream environmental governance theory and practice.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Ecology, Evolution, and Behavior PhD, Environmental Governance GC, or Public Policy and Administration PhD

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: The culminating activity (or part of the culminating activity) for a non-thesis master’s program. Considerable autonomy is granted to the academic unit in the design, administration, and evaluation of the comprehensive examination. May be attempted only after completion of all required core courses and admission to candidacy. Other conditions may be imposed by the academic unit responsible for the program. May not be used for a master’s thesis defense. Pass/fail only.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: A final comprehensive assessment of the knowledge and skills of a master’s student in the major field of study. A culminating activity taken in the last semester of a master’s program. Either graded or pass/fail.

Course Title: Introduction to Nonprofit Management and Collaboration
Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or both (alt yr)
Description: The course examines the implementation of public policy through nongovernmental organizations. Students will gain a general understanding of the history of philanthropy in selected nations and will explore the various social, economic, and political assumptions that found contemporary cross-sector delivery systems.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Explores issues, trends, ethics, and best practices in contract management from the pre-award phase through post-award.
Examines the study of public policy and its administration using the development and refinement of technical oral and written communication skills and the preparation of research critiques.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Public Policy and Administration PhD

Description: Introduction to different urban and rural political systems, governance and administration including variations in electoral structures, governing bodies, and an analysis of political parties, interest groups and emerging policy issues.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines the public policy process including stages, types, and the roles public servants play.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines the way in which organizations make an assessment of, control, and transfer risk.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines importance of citizen participation in policy processes, including the role of social capital.
Process of policymaking both within an agency and within the total governmental process, emphasizing policy and program planning, policy implementation and the value system of administrators.

Course Title: The Executive and the Administrative Process
Description: This course covers the powers and responsibilities of elected and appointed executives in the public sector. Concepts examined in the class include leadership and management, executive roles, management theories and styles, relationships with the separate branches of government and other actors in the political environment. The unique position of the executive between politics and administration and the relevant activities in policy formation through implementation form the basis of discussion.

Examines political, social, economic, and administrative theories that have shaped democratic government and its institutions and processes. Topics include prominent writings in both political and public administration theory.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Public Policy and Administration PhD

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Intergovernmental Relations. May be repeated for credit.

Course Title: Seminar in Environmental Policy and Administration
Description: Examines the major issues, policy choices, and actors in current environmental and natural resource policy. Attention is centered upon, but not limited to, U.S. policies and issues.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Public Policy and Administration PhD

Course Title: Selected Topics: Natural Resource and Environmental Policy
Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Natural Resource and Environmental Policy. May be repeated for credit.

Course Title: Selected Topics: Public Management Skills and Techniques
Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Public Management Skills and Techniques. May be repeated for credit.

Explores issues related to evaluation research and design with particular attention to design and critique of process, outcome, and impact evaluations and the utility of evaluation in performance monitoring.
Prerequisites: Completed the following:

Course Title: Decision-Making in Public and Nonprofit Management
Description: Designed to introduce decision theory and optimization techniques and tools in public and nonprofit organizations to provide basic techniques related to planning, monitoring, managing, and measuring program performance.

Addresses the theoretical and practical nexus between public policy and public opinion and the role that surveys play in that relationship. Students engage directly in advanced survey research through design, implementation, sampling, data collection, follow-up, analysis, and ethical considerations.
Prerequisites: Completed the following:

Description: Applies social science research design to advanced study of contemporary research questions in public policy and administration including advanced instruction in the development and presentation of research reports.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to Public Policy and Administration PhD
Completed at least 1 of the following:
  PUBADM607 - Advanced Public Administration Studies (3)
  PUBADM608 - Advanced Public Policy Studies (3)

Completion of 12 credits in the methodology sequence

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or both (alt yr)
Description: Examines mechanisms, assumptions, and measurement issues surrounding various forms of public policy implementation including the use of direct service delivery by public organizations, collaborative systems and the use of for-profit and nonprofit organizations.
Elementary distribution theory, statistical inference, and an introduction to multiple regression. Emphasis on practical applications.
Prerequisites: Completed the following:

Description: Explores more advanced techniques including multiple regression, logistic regression, dummy variables, multicollinearity, regression assumptions and time series modeling. Course meets for 5 weeks
Co-requisites: Completed or concurrently enrolled in:

Course Title: Selected Topics: Administrative Theory and Practice
Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Administrative Theory and Practice. May be repeated for credit.

Sources of power and duties of administrative agencies, rules and regulations made by agencies through investigation and hearings, judicial decisions and precedents relating to administrative activities.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Introduction to techniques used to assess the potential impacts of policy choices.

Examines the personnel/human resource management role as it has evolved in the public service sectors. Multiple responsibilities of personnel managers in the public and nonprofit sectors will be examined, and the link between public policy and personnel management is explored.
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
PUBADM500 - Administration in the Public Sector (3)

Description: Explores advanced practical applications of political, social, economic, and administrative theories related to local, regional, state, national, comparative policy questions.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to Public Policy and Administration PhD
Completed the following:
  PUBADM601 - Philosophy of Social Inquiry (3)
  PUBADM602 - Theories of Public Administration (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines importance of citizen participation in policy processes, including the role of social capital.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Background, objectives, scope, methods, and timeline of the thesis research. Considerable autonomy is granted to the academic unit in the design, administration, evaluation, and approval of the thesis proposal. Pass/fail only.

Course Title: Selected Topics: State and Local Government Policy and Administration
Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: State and Local Government Policy and Administration. May be repeated for credit.

Determination of fiscal policy, budgeting processes, and governmental forms of budgeting. Consideration of fiscal policy and processes in various program areas. Emphasis on the interface between technical and political processes.
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
PUBADM500 - Administration in the Public Sector (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Explores the unique political and legal environment facing nonprofits and best practices in effectively and efficiently managing human and financial resources.
Examination of ethical dilemmas facing civil servants and elected officials utilizing case studies, current ethics statutes, and approaches in the public administration literature to the subject.

Examines the various governance approaches used in diverse and complicated environmental and natural resource problems. It will examine these approaches as they are applied in the areas of water, land use, energy, and other natural resource areas.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Execution of a substantial exercise that demonstrates the ability to successfully and independently carry out a professional activity similar to what is encountered in the professional workplace; archival of the results of the project is required according to standards approved by the Graduate College. Pass/fail only.

Introduction to several methods of conducting surveys to explore the strengths and limitations of this mode of data collection including developing instruments and assessing results. Course meets for 5 weeks.
Co-requisites: Completed or concurrently enrolled in:

Description: Interviews, observation, focus group methods examined in relation to planning and public administration. Other topics include communication skills in terms of writing, presentation, interpersonal dialogue, and group process.
Prerequisites: Completed the following:

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines the process by which decisions are in made in legislative bodies, including parliamentary process and budgetary allocations.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Examines key issues in public financial management, including basic government accounting and regulations governing public spending.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: An early assessment of a student’s potential to complete a master’s program satisfactorily. Considerable autonomy is granted to the academic unit in the design, administration, and evaluation of the preliminary examination. Pass/fail only.

Course Title: Selected Topics: Comparative Public Administration and Planning Systems
Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Comparative Public Administration and Planning Systems. May be repeated for credit.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Explores issues related to leadership, mentoring and training employees, and working with others.

Explores inferential statistics with attention to hypothesis testing, cross-tabs with Chi-Square, independent samples t-test, ANOVA, association/correlation and simple regression using SPSS. Course meets for 5 weeks.
Co-requisites: Completed or concurrently enrolled in:

Description: Considers multiple aspects of climate change, global warming, and related issues such as mitigation, adaptation, resilience, and vulnerability in relation to public policy and administration. Considering climate change is defined through science, politics, competing perspectives, alternate and available solutions will frame the course.

Examines the various techniques for data collection, analysis, evaluation, and reporting in order to inform environmental decision-making by governmental, private sector, and nongovernmental policy actors.
Explores the key issues in the development of major energy policy choices in the U.S. with attention paid to issues with international ramification.
Introduction to descriptive statistics including central tendency, measures of dispersion, normal distribution, contingency tables, data collection and sampling using SPSS. Course meets for 5 weeks.

Course Title: State and Local Government Policy and Administration
Description: This course examines state and local government administration in a political and organizational context and the attendant interunit, intersector, and interjurisdictional cooperation and conflict in policy administration. Attention is paid to management in a federal system with a focus on nation-state-local relations.

Designed to introduce students to the broad field of public administration at the graduate level. The course surveys a number of important issues in contemporary public administration, including an emphasis on political, legal, economic and social institutions and processes.

Explores how the identification and amelioration of public health issues change over time. Current leading health threats, including the root causes, social drivers and resulting disparities, will be examined. The application of real-time analysis and intervention will be discussed. May be repeated for a maximum of 9 credits.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Public Health BA (online), Foundations of Public Health PracticeCertificate (online), Health and Human Behavior Certificate (online), Evidence-Based Public Health Certificate (online), or Community-Driven Health Solutions Certificate (online)

Description: Introduction to statistics and data analysis including descriptive statistics, confidence intervals, risk and odds, categorical data analysis, hypothesis testing, correlation, linear regression. Emphasis on quantitative reasoning, problem solving, communicating ideas, and applications in public health. Includes use of Excel and calculators to handle computations.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to one of the following: Public Health BA (online), or Public Health Certificate (online)
Completed the following:
  MATH108 - Intermediate Algebra (3)

Or satisfactory placement score or foundations of mathematics course

Description: Overview of the health care industry and the issues that confront this dynamic system, including the changing roles of components of the system as well as technical, economic, political and social forces responsible for those changes. Cross-listed with HLTH210, may be taken once for credit.

Course Title: Introduction to Health Science and Public Health (FS)
Description: This course offers an introduction to the art and science of public health and health sciences. The course describes the public health and healthcare systems in the United States, identifies disciplines of public health and health science, and explores the interrelationship between environmental factors, human behavior, and health policy in determining health outcomes. Cross-listed with HLTH110, may be taken once for credit.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Practical field experience in public health. Opportunity to apply knowledge and theory learned in classroom to practical setting. May be repeated for credit. Either graded or pass/fail.

Social change and community work relies on cross-sector collaboration. Investigates key tools and theories that empower and engage communities to address their own issues. Cross-listed with HLTH470, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Analyzes the relationship between the mental, emotional, and social dimensions of wellbeing. Covers evidence-based approaches to assessing and promoting these interrelated dimensions of wellbeing and empower individuals with the knowledge, skills, and strategies needed to enhance mental health, build resilience, and support the mental wellness of others. Cross-listed with HLTH356, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Description: Introduction to the online BA in Public Health (BAPH). Offers an introduction to public health and explores different disciplines within the field. The course will address the social determinants of health and explain how they influence personal and community health.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Public Health BA (online), or Public Health Certificate (online)

Course Title: Epidemiology for Clinical and Public Health Practice
Description: Epidemiological principles and their practical applications in clinical and public health settings. Study of the distribution and determinants of disease within human populations. Provides tools to critically assess, interpret, and apply epidemiological data to improve healthcare and public health outcomes. Cross-listed with HLTH480, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Fundamental exploration into the principles, theories, and essential components that underpin the field of public health. Designed to provide a comprehensive understanding of the historical, theoretical, and practical foundations of public health and skills necessary to address contemporary health issues. Cross-listed with HLTH310, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Description: Familiarizes students with the prominent theories, issues, and topics in the field of health communication with a range of topics, including illness and health, historical and contemporary issues, patient and provider experiences, cultural differences in health, public awareness/prevention/intervention campaigns, and the role of media and relationships in health communication.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to one of the following: Public Health BA (online), Public Health Certificate (online), or Community-Driven Health Solutions Certificate (online)

Description: Evaluates delivery of health programs from Idaho’s major urban areas to its rural counties. Coverage of program delivery models from local public health districts, Idaho Department of Health and Welfare, non-profit organizations, and for profit organizations. Particular focus on the importance of collaboration between various agencies and organizations to promote community health. Cross-listed with HLTH445, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Pathophysiology provides the basic link between the sciences of anatomy, physiology, and biochemistry and their application to clinical practice. Emphasizes the dynamic aspects of disease processes in the human body. This includes disruption of normal physiology and a “system approach” to focus on risk factors, symptomatology, diagnostic tools, and treatment modalities. Cross-listed with HLTH300, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Description: Provides an overview of methods and efforts to achieve measurable improvements in the efficiency, effectiveness, performance, accountability, outcomes, and other indicators of quality in services or processes, which achieve equity and improve the health of the community.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to one of the following: Public Health BA (online), or Public Health Certificate (online)

Description: Design of experiments, methods of analysis, interpretation and communication of results, and use of research to support evidence-based practice. Cross-listed with HLTH382, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Introduction to Greek and Latin prefixes, suffixes, combining forms and roots used in medical terminology, as well as the study of anatomical, physiological, and pathological terms, clinical procedures, abbreviations, and lab tests according to systems of the body. Medical terminology is treated as a medical language and clinical application is stressed. Cross-listed with HLTH101, may be taken once for credit.

Provides an in-depth exploration of public health issues and interventions tailored to rural communities. Examine the unique challenges and opportunities in promoting health and preventing disease within rural populations, focusing on strategies to address disparities and improve overall well-being. Gain a comprehensive understanding of the unique public health challenges facing rural communities and develop skills to design, implement, and evaluate effective interventions to improve population health outcomes in rural areas. Cross-listed with HLTH425, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of the biological, psychological, social, environmental, and cultural factors that influence health and wellbeing. Introduces models, theories, and public health methods associated with determinants of health. Topics include gender, ethnicity/race, relationships, socioeconomic status, built environment, community, political systems, stress and adverse childhood experiences, and culture and their influences on individual and community health. Cross-listed with HLTH305, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Description: Design and engage in a capstone project that synthesizes healthcare and/or public health concepts and addresses current health and wellness-related issues within various contexts.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Public Health BA (online)

Course Title: Ethical and Legal Considerations in Patient Care
Description: Covers ethical principles and legal frameworks necessary to navigate the complex landscape of patient care and healthcare delivery. Examination of practical implications in providing patient-centered care while upholding professional standards and legal obligations. Cross-listed with HLTH315, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Description: Introduction to practices of health and wellness emphasizing lifestyles and measures of health. This course will cover general concepts related to the human body and chronic and infectious diseases, as well as how organ systems are affected by disease. Cross-listed with HLTH355, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore or higher

Description: Supervised clinical experience.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
RADSCI385 - Radiologic Sciences Clinical Experience (4)

Completed the following:
RADSCI222 - Radiographic Positioning I (3)
Co-requisites:

Completed the following:

Designed to increase student resiliency when navigating the clinical setting as both a student and professional.

Completed the following:
RADSCI313 - Fluoroscopic and Contrast Media Examinations (2)

Completed the following:
RADSCI105 - Interprofessional Patient Care Skills Lab (2)

Prerequisites:

RADSCI104 - Patient Assessment (1)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Upper-division students may earn credits in independent study, usually through directed reading or by completing a special project. Students may earn no more than 4 credits in a semester and no more than 6 credits during a single academic year, and no more than a total of 9 credits may be used to meet degree requirements or university graduation requirements. Before enrolling for independent study, a student must obtain the approval of the department chair, acting on the recommendation of the instructor who will be supervising the independent study. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Course Title: Law and Ethics in Radiologic Sciences
Description: Critical analysis of the theory and development of health laws, professional liability and ethics related to radiologic science. The course will examine current policies and ethical challenges that affect the practice of medical imaging.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
RADSCI242 - Radiographic Positioning II (3)

Description: Concepts of pharmacology as it relates to the delivery of contrast medias and selected medications associated with contrast media reactions.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Radiologic Sciences BS, or Radiologic Sciences Certificates Admission

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.
Supervised clinical experience. Terminal clinical competency will be validated.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
RADSCI405 - Radiologic Sciences Clinical Experience (4)

Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
RADSCI105 - Interprofessional Patient Care Skills Lab (2)

Description: Introduction to the set up and operation of a radiology department including design principles, projection of demands, and providing for growth and development. Structural and shielding requirements will be discussed.
Introduction to the exposure factors, formulas, techniques, and tools employed when acquiring digital radiographic images and their impact on image quality and patient radiation dose.
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:

Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
RADSCI311 - Radiobiology and Protection (3)

Description: An interprofessional disciplinary team approach is used to teach basic patient care skills and interventions to restore and protect health.
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:

RADSCI200 - Principles of Radiographic Imaging I (3)
Co-requisites:

RADSCI223 - Laboratory Practicum I (1)

Description: Topics will be selected from current health care issues. These topics will be presented for discussion by appropriate health care professionals.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Radiologic Sciences BS

Description: Explores the resettlement process in the United States. Provides knowledge and skills needed to assist in the resettlement experience of refugees. Examination of personal values and beliefs and their impacts on practice are integral. Cross-listed with SOCWRK 407, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Social Work BA

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student’s major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Explores cardiovascular disease management and presents the pathophysiology, diagnosis, and management of common cardiovascular diseases that Respiratory Therapists will encounter in clinical practice. Builds on the development of care plans and student-lead related discussion forums on topics related to specific disease entities of their choosing.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Respiratory Care MS

Description: Experience in critical care units with patients, techniques and equipment as applied to mechanical ventilation and artificial airways. Recommended completion of RESPCARE 228.

Equipment and basic therapeutics for respiratory care. Compressed gas cylinders, oxygen delivery devices, hyperinflation, airway clearance techniques, pulse oximetry, capnography, large and small volume nebulizers, MDI/DPI devices, and introduction to artificial airways.
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
RESPCARE203 - Foundations of Respiratory Care (3)
RESPCARE208 - Clinical Practicum I (1)

Course Title: Respiratory Care Therapeutics and Introduction to Mechanical Ventilation Lab
Description: Use and application of hyperinflation therapy devices, chest physiotherapy, suction devices, oral endotracheal intubation and adult mechanical ventilation.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
RESPCARE203 - Foundations of Respiratory Care (3)
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
RESPCARE223 - Respiratory Care Therapeutics and Introduction to Mechanical Ventilation (4)
RESPCARE228 - Clinical Practicum II (4)

Course Title: Leadership and Management for Health Care Professionals
Description: Extensive examination of current practices/trends of techniques used in the leadership of the health care environment. Emphasis will be placed upon specific skill sets used by the managers of today's workforce.
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
RESPCARE355 - Professional Communications in Health Care (3)

Description: Reflection on growth and future plans in respiratory care and preparation for credentialing examinations offered by the National Board for Respiratory Care. Emphasis will be placed on the understanding of branching-logic examinations as well as computer-based, multiple-choice examinations related to the clinical practice of respiratory care.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
RESPCARE323 - Neonatal and Pediatric Respiratory Care (3)
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
RESPCARE423 - Advanced Neonatal, Pediatric and Adult Critical Care (3)

Course Title: Advanced Pharmacology for the Respiratory Care Practitioner
Description: Explores basic principles of pharmacology including pharmacokinetics, receptor modulation, drug metabolism, drug toxicity and pharmacogenetics. Medications will be addressed by drug class that the Respiratory Care Specialist would encounter in patients in critical care, floor care, and care navigation that have important considerations for practitioners. Drug classes that will be covered include autonomic, cardiovascular, renal, smooth muscle, central nervous system hematologic, endocrine, antimicrobial, and chemotherapeutic medications. May be repeated once for credit.

Explores pulmonary disease management and presents the pathophysiology, diagnosis, and management of common respiratory diseases that Respiratory Therapists encounter in clinical practice. Includes the development of care plans and student-lead online discussions related to specific disease entities of their choosing.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Respiratory Care MS

Description: Research project carried out by the student in collaboration with a supervising member of the Respiratory Care faculty.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
HLTH382 - Research Methods in Health (3)
RESPCARE282 - Introduction to Evidence-Based Inquiry (3)
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
RESPCARE323 - Neonatal and Pediatric Respiratory Care (3)

Description: In-depth practice, application and understanding of a variety of state-of-the-art critical care ventilators used to ventilate adults.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
RESPCARE223 - Respiratory Care Therapeutics and Introduction to Mechanical Ventilation (4)
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
RESPCARE303 - Advanced Mechanical Ventilation (4)
RESPCARE308 - Clinical Practicum III (4)

Description: Students will develop foundational knowledge regarding gathering and interpretation of laboratory tests, radiographic images and cardiopulmonary diagnostics.

Completed the following:
RESPCARE220 - Cardiopulmonary Renal Physiology (3)
RESPCARE203 - Foundations of Respiratory Care (3)
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
RESPCARE223 - Respiratory Care Therapeutics and Introduction to Mechanical Ventilation (4)

Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
RESPCARE303 - Advanced Mechanical Ventilation (4)
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:

Description: Equipment and mechanical ventilators specific to neonatal and pediatric patients. High frequency ventilation, neonatal resuscitation, exogenous surfactant, basic care of neonates, and pediatric specific ventilation techniques.

Completed the following:
RESPCARE303 - Advanced Mechanical Ventilation (4)
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
RESPCARE323 - Neonatal and Pediatric Respiratory Care (3)

Description: Online discussions of topics related to respiratory care.

Description: Students, working individually and in teams, will find and use studies and articles from a variety of healthcare disciplines to develop an evidence-based literature review and a culminating group project that addresses a current respiratory care process/problem from the perspective of several different members of the healthcare team.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to Respiratory Care, AS Track BS, or Respiratory Care, AAS or AHS Track BS
Completed the following:

Description: Theory and application of physics, chemistry, basic therapeutics, and disease management for respiratory therapists. Topics to include oxygen and carbon dioxide transport, humidity, aerosol therapy, airway clearance, hyperinflation, medical gasses, and patient monitoring.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Respiratory Care BS
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
RESPCARE204 - Foundations of Respiratory Care Lab (2)

Focus is on understanding of instructional design, development, and assessment components, as well as identification and development of objectives based in learning and/or health promotion theory.
Prerequisites: Declared or admitted to Respiratory Care MS

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Description: Upper-division students may earn credits in independent study, usually through directed reading or by completing a special project. Students may earn no more than 4 credits in a semester and no more than 6 credits during a single academic year, and no more than a total of 9 credits may be used to meet degree requirements or university graduation requirements.
