Description: Use ArcGIS to improve planning and decision-making by applying GIS technology to a variety of planning related issues. Students will learn how to use open-source data to create maps and visuals with the ability to tell stories, compare scenarios, and assist in decision making.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Must have a class standing of upper-division
permission of instructor

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Selected urban studies and community development topics under faculty direction.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Introduces and develops essential skills for engaging with and leading communities through processes of change, conflict, or growth. Specific topics and examples will vary by term and instructor. Students will have the opportunity to apply and practice skills with instructor guidance. May be repeated for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Description: Explores how cities and communities are built and revitalized. Introduces contemporary and historical policies and plans that shape the urban and regional environment.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of sophomore

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Selected urban studies and community development topics under faculty direction.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Applies theory and sharpens skills while addressing a real-world problem. Students identify a problem, gather data, consult with community members and experts, recommend solutions, and communicate their findings to stakeholders.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to Urban Studies and Community Development BA
Completed the following:
  SPS240 - Data in Public Service (3)

Must have a class standing of senior or higher

Description: Allows students to explore different dimensions of urban sustainability through real examples, imagined futures, and tangible plans for moving urban areas towards sustainable utopias.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Introduces principles that underlie the practice of planning, including physical planning, permitted development, planning application process, governmental structure, land use law, zoning, subdivision regulations and comprehensive planning. Explores the roles different organizations and stakeholders take in planning.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Must have a class standing of upper-division
Permission of Instructor

Description: Planning, conducting, and reporting the results of in-depth conversations and semi-structured interviews, enriching transcripts, and storytelling. Cross-listed with UX-PRO 362, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Best user research practices to protect researchers, participants, and clients complete training in human subjects research. Cross-listed with UX-PRO 361, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Introduction to, and applications of, core design concepts including empathy and journey map concepts. Collaborate to create visualizations that translate user research into impactful implications for design. Cross-listed with UX-PRO 364, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Practice ethical observations using direct, remote, and participatory observational techniques. Discover the importance of context and the difference between what people say and what they do. Cross-listed with UX-PRO 363, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Utilizing the tools of user design from field notes to storytelling and visualization techniques to communicate insights of research. Universal accessibility, inclusive design, and how to avoid excluding portions of your audience. Cross-listed with UX-PRO 366, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Propose, negotiate, and conduct an independent UX research project, or assist on a faculty project. Participate across the full research process. Define objectives, select methods, manage the collection and analysis of appropriate data, and deliver impactful insights that your stakeholders value. Cross-listed with UX-PRO 469, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed at least 1 of the following:
  UX360 - Working in the UX Space (1)
  UX-PRO360 - Working in the UX Space (1)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  UX361 - Ethical User Research (1)
  UX-PRO366 - Communicating User Research (1)
  UX-PRO361 - Ethical User Research (1)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  UX362 - Asking and Listening (1)
  UX-PRO362 - Asking and Listening (1)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  UX365 - Go Deeper with Theory (1)
  UX-PRO363 - Contextual Inquiry (1)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  UX364 - Design Thinking for Better UX (1)
  UX-PRO364 - Design Thinking for Better UX (1)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  UX365 - Go Deeper with Theory (1)
  UX-PRO365 - Go Deeper with Theory (1)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  UX366 - Communicating User Research (1)
  UX-PRO366 - Communicating User Research (1)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  UX367 - Just Enough Research (1)
  UX-PRO367 - Just Enough Research (1)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  UX368 - Planning a Productive Capstone (1)
  UX-PRO368 - Planning a Productive Capstone (1)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Identifying appropriate methods for diverse problems, applying multiple methods to develop more robust triangulated data, and synthesizing complex data to arrive at compelling insights. Cross-listed with UX-PRO 367, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Pre-capstone project. Identify potential stakeholders, negotiate a design brief, and prepare a scope of work proposal. Identify possible sampling and recruitment strategies, explore appropriate methods, and plan a schedule to gather and analyze data and report your results in a timely manner. Cross-listed with UX-PRO 368, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to one of the following: User Experience Research Certificate, or User Experience Research Minor
Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Qualitative user research has deep roots in the social sciences, especially anthropology. Increase your knowledge of the conceptual foundations of user research to reach beyond superficial findings and deliver transformative insights. Cross-listed with UX-PRO 365, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Diverse applications of qualitative user research in public and private sectors. Relationship between usability testing, design thinking, and ethnographic inquiry. Cross-listed with UX-PRO 360, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Best user research practices to protect researchers, participants, and clients complete training in human subjects research. Cross-listed with UX 361, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to User Research (UX) Professional Certificate
Or admission to a fully online undergraduate degree program

Declared or admitted to User Research (UX) Professional Certificate

Description: Practice ethical observations using direct, remote, and participatory observational techniques. Discover the importance of context and the difference between what people say and what they do. Cross-listed with UX 363, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to User Research (UX) Professional Certificate
Or admission to a fully online undergraduate degree program

Description: Diverse applications of qualitative user research in public and private sectors. Relationship between usability testing, design thinking, and ethnographic inquiry. Cross-listed with UX 360, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to User Research (UX) Professional Certificate
Or admission to a fully online undergraduate degree program

Description: Utilizing the tools of user design from field notes to storytelling and visualization techniques to communicate insights of research. Universal accessibility, inclusive design, and how to avoid excluding portions of your audience. Cross-listed with UX 366, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to User Research (UX) Professional Certificate
Or admission to a fully online undergraduate degree program

Description: Pre-capstone project. Identify potential stakeholders, negotiate a design brief, and prepare a scope of work proposal. Identify possible sampling and recruitment strategies, explore appropriate methods, and plan a schedule to gather and analyze data and report your results in a timely manner. Cross-listed with UX 368, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to User Research (UX) Professional Certificate
Or admission to a fully online undergraduate degree program

Description: Identifying appropriate methods for diverse problems, applying multiple methods to develop more robust triangulated data, and synthesizing complex data to arrive at compelling insights. Cross-listed with UX 367, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Declared or admitted to User Research (UX) Professional Certificate
Or admission to a fully online undergraduate degree program

Description: Students engage in project work on multi-disciplinary, team-based, research projects. Projects have significant engineering components, using math and sciences toward creative applications needed to solve engineering problems. Topics considered in the courses are those necessary for the success of the VIP project. Cross-listed with BIOL401 and ENVSCI401, may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits. Recommended upper-division standing.

Orientation to team-based research projects coached by faculty and graduate students. Team members contribute to the project's success by exploring different roles on large multidisciplinary design/discovery teams. Skills learned include a basic level of professional (e.g., communication, project management, time management) and technical skills (e.g., lab skills, scientific method application). Topics considered in the courses are those necessary for the success of the VIP project. Course and topic(s) may be repeated up to 4 semesters for credit.

Students engage in project work with faculty and graduate students on multi-disciplinary, team-based, research projects. Participants demonstrate advanced research skills. Topics considered in the courses are those necessary for the success of the VIP project. Course and topic may be repeated up to 6 semesters for credit. Recommended upper-division standing.

Reinforces professional and technical skills developed at the 200 - 500 level through work on team-based, research projects. Doctoral students serve as research leaders (which may include research on dissertation topic) and are responsible for modeling the behavior, technical expertise, and leadership of a professional researcher and project leader while mentoring students of all levels in support of the team’s success. Roles include comprehensive project management, objective setting/clarification, role definition and assignment, teaching, leading, mentoring team members,  and working with the professor to evaluate team member performance. Course topic is based on the VIP project and design challenges considered are those necessary for the success of the VIP project. Course and topic may be repeated up to 6 semesters for credit.

Develops important professional and technical skills through work on team-based, research projects. Graduate students serve as project managers and are responsible for modeling the behavior, technical expertise, and leadership of a professional researcher and project leader. Roles include teaching, leading, and developing members of large multidisciplinary design/discovery teams. Course topic is based on the VIP project, and design challenges considered are those necessary for the success of the VIP project. Topics may be repeated up to 6 semesters. Either graded or pass/fail.

Exploration of VIP projects through direct engagement with VIP faculty and students in seminars, meetings, interviews, and other guided experiences.  Introduction to success in team-based research projects. Learn about the skills and mindsets needed to make progress on ambitious, multi-disciplinary,  long-term projects.  Create and connect academic, career, and personal goals related to VIP projects.

Course Title: Topics in Germanic Literature and Film
Description: A focused study of German speaking literature in translation and/or films organized around a theme.  Frequent writing assignments. Course conducted in English. May be repeated once for credit with a different topic.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Description: A focused study of Hispanic literature in translation organized around a historical period, a genre, a movement, an author, or a theme. Topics will vary each time the course is offered. Frequent writing assignments. Course conducted in English. May be repeated for credit with permission of instructor. Available once as an upper-division elective toward the Spanish major or minor if writing assignments are done in Spanish.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: A focused study of international film organized around a specific culture, genre, movement, historical period, director, or theme. Topics will vary each time the course is offered. Frequent writing assignments. Course conducted in English. Course may be repeated for credit, topics are not repeatable.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Structure and substance of Japanese culture. Development of Japanese culture from prehistory to present, the development of the Japanese worldview, cultural patterns, beliefs, behaviors, values, and norms that are reflected in Japanese culture today.

Theories of second language (L2) development and of changing pedagogical practices in L2 secondary classrooms; historical trajectory of Second Language Acquisition theory and teaching methods, emphasizing contemporary approaches; integration of theoretical insights and practical implications  specific to the language. Topics include facilitating input and output activities for intercultural competence and interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational communication at the beginner and intermediate levels. National and state content standards, and innovative technologies for L2 practice.
Survey of factual and fictitious contexts of King Arthur with consideration of gender roles in variations of Arthurian Legends.
Screening and discussion of films from China, Taiwan, and Hong Kong for their historical, cultural, thematic, and aesthetic content in the context of modern Chinese cultures.
Prerequisites:
Completed at least 1 of the following:
HIST121 - Asian History from Antiquity to the Present (FH) (3)
FILM220 - Cinema History and Aesthetics (FA) (3)
GLOBAL101 - Global Studies: Conflict, Cooperation, and Change (FS) (3)
GLOBAL201 - Around the Globe: World Regions in a time of Connection, Crisis, and Change (3)
POLS305 - Comparative Global Politics (3)
POLS306 - International Relations: Actors, Interactions, and Methods (3)

Description: Focused study of Germanic culture organized around a specific theme. Frequent writing assignments. Conducted in English. May be repeated once for credit with different topic.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Description: In this Service-Learning class, students will mentor international students to help them integrate socially and culturally into the American college experience. Students will meet weekly with the international students in class to assist them with linguistic and cultural activities. May be repeated once for credit.

Study of the integration and implementation of technology-enhanced language learning in a communicative, proficiency-based context. Draws on the foundations of foreign language teaching and learning to evaluate instructional technologies that impact second language development in a classroom setting. Recommended: WORLD 510.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
WORLD510 - Foundations of Second Language Development (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Advanced study of a specialized topic; design and completion of a project may be included in the study. The student works with a high degree of Independence to meet well-defined goals under the supervision of a member of the graduate faculty. Requires submission of a completed Application for Graduate Independent Study prior to the deadline specified in the academic calendar. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken. Either graded or pass/fail.

Overview of theoretical principles of second language (L2) development by examining the cognitive, social, and linguistic factors and features that impact the process. Analysis and evaluation of theoretical principles for L2 development in a proficiency-based framework.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
WORLD410 - Theories and Methods for Teaching a Second Language in Secondary Classrooms (3)

Description: Incorporating feature films, novels, music, and original sources in translation, we will explore the culture and history of the Korean peninsula, both South and North, including daily life, art, religion, gender, cuisine and Korean popular culture. Course conducted in English.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division

Course Title: Understanding and Assessing Literacy for Second Language Learners
Description: This course builds on the foundational concepts learned in WORLD 410 to understand, integrate, and assess literacy within the context of second language learning. Students will identify the dynamic and multi-layered definition for literacy and second language learning according to the American Council on the Teaching of Foreign Language. Specifically, they will identify how literacy is integrated into the World Readiness Standards and every fiber of the interpersonal, presentational, interpretive, and intercultural modes of communication. As such, they will learn different ways to assess second language (L2) learners’ literacy across the modes of communication at beginner and intermediate proficiency levels using an Integrated Performance Assessment model.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
WORLD410 - Theories and Methods for Teaching a Second Language in Secondary Classrooms (3)
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
ED-CIFS401 - Professional Year - Teaching Experience II (3)

Description: Creation of professional portfolio to showcase language proficiency, highlight academic growth, and document specific achievements. Students will also explore career opportunities and create a tailored resume. Project-based.  Recommended completion of FREN 202, GERM 202, or SPAN 202.

Focused study of literary works by contemporary Arab writers in English translation. Particular emphasis on analysis of gender roles and identity in the context of the authors' unique social and political environments. Frequent writing assignments. Course conducted in English.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Upper-division students may earn credits in independent study, usually through directed reading or by completing a special project. Students may earn no more than 4 credits in a semester and no more than 6 credits during a single academic year, and no more than a total of 9 credits may be used to meet degree requirements or university graduation requirements. Before enrolling for independent study, a student must obtain the approval of the department chair, acting on the recommendation of the instructor who will be supervising the independent study. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken.
Screening and discussion of films from Japan for their historical, cultural, thematic, and aesthetic content in the context of modern Japanese culture.

HIST121 - Asian History from Antiquity to the Present (FH) (3)

Description: Develops a dynamic understanding of contemporary Korean popular culture and Korean society by taking an interdisciplinary approach to a variety of topics. Explores the evolution of Korean popular culture in a Korean and global context. Korean popular culture will be used as a window through which Korean society will be viewed more broadly, in its many facets.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Course Title: Theories and Methods for Teaching a Second Language in Secondary Classrooms
Description: An overview of theories of second language (L2) development and of changing pedagogical practices in L2 secondary classrooms. Topics include understanding how to facilitate input and output activities to foster intercultural competence and improve interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational communication at the beginner and intermediate levels. National and state content standards as well as innovative technologies to augment L2 practice will also be covered.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed at least 1 of the following:
  LING305 - Introduction to Language Studies (3)
  SPAN415 - Introduction to Spanish Linguistics (3)

18 upper-division language credits
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
ED-CIFS301 - Teaching Experience I (1 - 2)
ED-CIFS302 - Learning and Instruction (4)

Description: Introduction to the philosophy of Confucianism as the foundation of Chinese culture. Students will explore how Confucianism provided a framework for the development of traditional Chinese moral standards, family values, education, political philosophy, civil responsibility, and attitudes toward the natural world. Cross-listed with PHIL 322, may be taken once for credit.

Develops life skills and attitudes needed to set and to achieve educational and personal goals. Explores university resources, services, and policies. Emphasis placed on being a successful student in the Department of World Languages.

Survey of contemporary China including cultural and historical roots, nation-building efforts, political, economic and social systems, and domestic and foreign policies. Discussion of Hong Kong, Tibet, and Taiwan. Cross-listed with POLS 433, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Completed at least 1 of the following:
HIST121 - Asian History from Antiquity to the Present (FH) (3)
GLOBAL101 - Global Studies: Conflict, Cooperation, and Change (FS) (3)
GLOBAL201 - Around the Globe: World Regions in a time of Connection, Crisis, and Change (3)
POLS305 - Comparative Global Politics (3)
POLS306 - International Relations: Actors, Interactions, and Methods (3)

Description: Multidisciplinary analysis of the richness and diversity of Chinese culture and civilization, including history, philosophy, religion, and literature. Topics include the aesthetic aspect of Chinese characters, Confucianism and Buddhism in Chinese culture, family values and filial piety, Chinese medicine and cuisine, the art of Chinese calligraphy and painting, traditional festivals, poetry, and short stories.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Course Title: Understanding and Assessing Literacy for Second Language Learners
Description: Building on the foundational concepts from WORLD 410/501 to understand, integrate, and assess literacy within second language (L2) learning, students identify multi-layered definitions for literacy and second language learning (ACTFL); integrate literacy with World-Readiness Standards and  interpersonal, presentational, interpretive modes and intercultural competence for communication in a global world; learn how to assess second language (L2) learners’ literacy across communication modes at beginner and intermediate proficiency levels using an Integrated Performance Assessment model.

Advances the level of digital fluency for language learners and develops skills to effectively and ethically interpret information, design content, discover knowledge and communicate ideas in our digitally connected world. Explores a variety of digital toolsets to prepare students for assignments in advanced language courses, as well as contemporary professional life. Project-based.

Course Title: Topics in French and Francophone Literature
Description: A focused study of French and/or Francophone literature in translation organized around a historical period, a genre, a movement, an author, or a theme. Topics will vary each time the course is offered. Frequent writing assignments. Course conducted in English. May be repeated for credit with permission of instructor. Available once as an upper-division elective toward the French major or minor if writing assignments are done in French.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Description: Survey of contemporary South and North Korea including cultural and historical roots, and political, economic, and social systems. Analysis of popular culture, including K-wave film, music, and television. Issues of gender roles in Korean society will also be studied. Course conducted in English.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed at least 1 of the following:
  HIST121 - Asian History from Antiquity to the Present (FH) (3)
  GLOBAL101 - Global Studies: Conflict, Cooperation, and Change (FS) (3)
  GLOBAL201 - Around the Globe: World Regions in a time of Connection, Crisis, and Change (3)
  POLS305 - Comparative Global Politics (3)
  POLS306 - International Relations: Actors, Interactions, and Methods (3)

Must have a class standing of upper-division or higher

Description: Introduction to the ethical and effective use of storytelling on social media platforms for the benefit of a community. Practice identifying and using narrative elements to responsibly promote content that engages and inspires audiences. Topics will include characterization, thematic significance, identity development, types of content, shared purpose, and brand voice.

Course Title: Style and the Future of Writing
Description: Explores the intersection of rhetorical style and the future of writing with focus on individual style, voice, and diction in writing. Equips writers with a deep understanding of rhetorical principles and strategies to use language to shape perceptions, influence beliefs, and craft compelling narratives that resonate with audiences. Empathizes humanist approaches to content creation with emerging technologies and techniques.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
Course Not Found

Course Title: Writing for Nonprofits and Social Media
Description: Study of content strategy for nonprofits and how to connect with those who believe in their purpose. Analyze an organization’s values, identify specific goals, craft compelling stories, create posts that align with those values, and select the right social media channels to distribute content to help organizations achieve their mission.
Prerequisites:
Completed at least 1 of the following:
WRITE212 - Introduction to Technical Communication (3)
SPS301 - Leadership in Public Service (3)
UX362 - Asking and Listening (1)
AE302 - Entrepreneurship and Innovation in the Creative Sector (3)

Course Title: Topics in Professional and Public Writing
Description: Explores current topics, developments, and issues related to professional and public writing. May be repeated for a total of six credits.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)
WRITE113 - Introduction to Professional and Public Writing (3)

Course Title: Teaching Readers of Literary Texts in English Language Arts Classrooms
Description: Explore approaches to reading instruction that promote student dialogue around texts and include reading young adult literature. Develop strategies for planning and implementing reading instruction in secondary English language arts classrooms.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Course Title: Inquiring Into Classroom Practices and Curricula
Description: Students develop and practice teacher inquiry stances and strategies. Students apply their inquiries by revising and re-imagining their instructional practices. This is the first-course in a year-long sequence.

Course Title: Introduction to Professional and Public Writing
Description: An introduction to the field of professional and public writing. Explores key skills for the field, critical challenges writers must address today and in the future, career options and pathways, and approaches to professional development.

Study and write for the public in a variety of nonfiction genres. Develop and refine individual style, sharpen research and writing strategies in an area of interest, and adapt content for specific audiences outside the university.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Description: Equips content creators, technical writers, and public writers with practical skills in using AI to enhance their work. Includes a range of AI tools to improve writing quality, streamline processes, and adapt to evolving workplace demands in professional writing. Emphasizes context-specific AI use, including ethical decision-making, audience awareness, text revision, and situation analysis.

Centers on how writing circulates by connecting the study of professional and public writing with opportunities to write with/in local communities. Includes advanced practice in field research, consultation and collaboration with writers, and production of audience-informed texts.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
WRITE201 - Writing for Public Audiences (3)

Description: Preparation for consulting with writers in the Boise State Writing Center. Emphasis on the theoretical foundations of writing center work, including understanding writing as a cognitive and social act, managing interpersonal dynamics, responding to writing-in-progress, and employing rhetorical grammar principles
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in at least 1 of the following:
WRITE293 - Internship (1 - 12)
WRITE493 - Internship (1 - 12)

Description: Study of principles of effective proposal development and grant writing for a variety of business and nonprofit contexts. Focus on identifying viable funding sources, researching and assessing requests/calls for proposals, and developing effective proposals.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed the following:
  ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Completed at least 1 of the following:
  WRITE212 - Introduction to Technical Communication (3)
  AE302 - Entrepreneurship and Innovation in the Creative Sector (3)

Course Title: Assessing Readers and Writers in Secondary Classrooms
Description: Inquire into current topics and trends in reading and writing assessment in secondary English language arts classrooms. Critically examine, develop, and practice using tools and methods for assessing student learning.
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
ED-CIFS302 - Learning and Instruction (4)

Course Title: Capstone in Professional and Public Writing (FF)
Description: Extensive revision of written work in professional and public writing courses and creation of a portfolio. Reflection on personal experiences, professional development, and transferable skills.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of senior

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Designed to provide students with professional experiences, regardless of their major. Students will develop their professional network alongside a mentor at a Treasure Valley employer. Time spent on site with employers and in a weekly class session. The class sessions are designed to unpack what the students are learning on the job, attend interactive workshops, engage with dynamic guest leaders from partner employers, and learn skills that translate directly to a professional setting. No more than 12 credits of Work U and/or internship may be applied towards graduation requirements.

Investigate leveraging digital technologies and services such as user analytics and search engine algorithms in the development of digital value. Practice implementing digital information strategies to create useful, relevant, and engaging social media content.

Develop strategies to identify opportunities for using name, image, and likeness that are consistent with brand and values. Introduction to tools and techniques to use social media platforms in safe and healthy ways.

Course Title: Integrating the English Language Arts in Curriculum and Instruction
Description: Create instructional plans that facilitate inclusive and dialogic classroom communities and integrate the English language arts: reading, writing, listening, speaking, viewing, and representing.
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
ED-CIFS401 - Professional Year - Teaching Experience II (3)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Upper-division students may earn credits in independent study, usually through directed reading or by completing a special project. Description: Students practice and publicly share their inquiries into their classroom practices and curricula within and beyond the course community. This is the second-course in a year-long sequence..

Completed the following:
WRITE577 - Inquiring Into Classroom Practices and Curricula (1)

Course Title: Teaching Writers in English Language Arts Classrooms
Description: Explore approaches to writing instruction that focus on student inquiry and writing processes. Develop strategies for planning and implementing writing instruction in secondary English language arts classrooms.

Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Course Title: Boise State Writing Project Invitational Institute
Description: Students engage in the National Writing Project’s six social practices of writing and reading for personal and professional purposes; going public with practice through a teaching demonstration; learning/engaging with the profession; collaborating with/responding to one another as writers, readers, teachers, and learners; leading by becoming thinking partners with colleagues; and advocating for inclusive and equitable conditions for teachers and learners.
Prerequisites: Must apply and be invited to participate

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. No more than 12 internship credits may be used to meet degree requirements or university graduation requirements.

Explores rhetorical roots of persuasion, with an emphasis on the relationship between writers and their audiences and the understanding of power dynamics and other ethical considerations. Analyze, write, and workshop persuasive texts.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed the following:
  ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Permission of instructor

Description: Learn to develop, lead, and evaluate effective team writing projects in organizational settings, including community-based, international, remote, and hybrid collaborations. Acquire and practice the leadership knowledge and skills to build writing teams, set direction for work efforts, advocate for resources, and communicate organizational values, while creating and maintaining inclusive, ethical, and effective teams.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
ENGL102 - Writing and Rhetoric II (FW) (3)

Description: A study of approaches to communicate complex ideas clearly for those considering a career in technical communication or professionals in other fields who must communicate complex ideas to audiences outside their field. Topics include career exploration, instructional writing, information design, visual design, and rhetorical strategies.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
WRITE212 - Introduction to Technical Communication (3)

Description: With a community of colleagues, reflect on classroom instruction and inquire into interactions with learners in secondary English language arts classrooms. Prepare materials and professional story for your post-graduation goals. This course supports teacher candidates’ classroom teaching during the student teaching semester.

Description: An introduction to editing workplace documents so that audiences can understand them easily and use them efficiently. Topics include copyediting, comprehensive editing, proofreading, principles of plain language, working with authors, and preparing documents for publication.

Explores the field of technical communication with a focus on creating practical documents and presentations for professional and workplace settings. Topics include document design, usability, accessibility, identifying user needs, developing technical graphics, and collaborating effectively.

Description: Places the user at the forefront of each stage of the problem-solving process. Apply user research to design artifacts that enhance the user's experience including developing and conducting usability tests. Topics include persona development, prototyping, design thinking, and accessibility.

Completed at least 1 of the following:
WRITE212 - Introduction to Technical Communication (3)

The general anatomy, physiology, and developmental biology of insects, and ecological and evolutionary relationships and interactions of insects with humans. Field trips to collect and identify local species.

Completed the following:
BIOL191 - Biology I: Introduction to Cell and Molecular Biology (FN) (4)
BIOL192 - Biology II: Introduction to the Diversity of Life (4)

Description: The evolutionary development of vertebrate anatomy, fishes through mammals. Dissection of the shark, salamander, and cat plus demonstrations of other vertebrate types.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
BIOL191 - Biology I: Introduction to Cell and Molecular Biology (FN) (4)
BIOL192 - Biology II: Introduction to the Diversity of Life (4)

Description: The biology of mammals: ecology, life histories, reproduction, classification, identification, distribution, and adaptations. One weekend field trip.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of graduate or higher

Description: Functional aspects of human tissues and organ systems with emphasis on regulatory and homeostatic mechanisms.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of graduate or higher

Description: Classification, identification, evolution, ecological relationships, behavior, and life histories of fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals. Two weekend field trips.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
BIOL191 - Biology I: Introduction to Cell and Molecular Biology (FN) (4)
BIOL192 - Biology II: Introduction to the Diversity of Life (4)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description:
To earn graduate credit you must have a 3.00 cumulative GPA and no more than 12 credits may be applied toward a graduate degree or second undergraduate degree. Some graduate programs, however, accept only 3 internships credits. Practicum/Internship cannot be repeated to improve a grade. Either graded or pass/fail.
Notes: An undergraduate internship is an entry level employment experience related to the discipline. The graduate intern already has an undergraduate degree and is expected to perform with a higher level of responsibility, decision-making authority, and accomplishment.

The evolutionary development of vertebrate anatomy, fishes through mammals with a focus on form and function. Dissection of the shark, salamander, and cat plus demonstrations of other vertebrate types.
Prerequisites:
Complete all of the following
Completed the following:
  BIOL304 - Biology III: Foundations of Ecology and Evolution (4)

Declared or admitted to Biology BS

Description: This course focuses on the concepts and processes of animal behavior, with particular emphasis on proximate perspectives. The history of the study of animal behavior, behavioral genetics, the nervous system and behavior, hormones and behavior, ontogeny of behavior, learning and motivation, and other aspects of behavior such as migration, orientation, and navigation will be presented.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of graduate or higher

Description: The taxonomy and ecology of the insects most commonly encountered in freshwater environments. Emphasis on identification and biology of individual taxa, aquatic insect community ecology, environmental pollution assessment, and natural resource management.
Prerequisites:
Completed at least 1 of the following:
BIOL304 - Biology III: Foundations of Ecology and Evolution (4)
BIOL323 - Ecology (4)

Description: The taxonomy and ecology of the insects most commonly encountered in freshwater environments. Emphasis on identification and biology of individual taxa, aquatic insect community ecology, environmental pollution assessment, and natural resource management.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of graduate or higher

Description: Birds as examples of biological principles: classification, identification, ecology, behavior, life histories, distribution, and adaptations of birds. Two weekend field trips.
Prerequisites:
Completed at least 1 of the following:
BIOL304 - Biology III: Foundations of Ecology and Evolution (4)
BIOL323 - Ecology (4)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Advanced study of a specialized topic; design and completion of a project may be included in the study. The student works with a high degree of Independence to meet well-defined goals under the supervision of a member of the graduate faculty. Requires submission of a completed Application for Graduate Independent Study prior to the deadline specified in the academic calendar. An independent study cannot be substituted for a course regularly offered at Boise State, nor can independent study credits be used to improve a grade in a course the student has already taken. Either graded or pass/fail.

The physiology of flight, cardiovascular, pulmonary, digestive, water and electrolyte, egg, and reproductive physiology are covered. Correlations between unique aspects of avian structure and function are emphasized.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of graduate or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: The conduct of topical research, assigned readings or literature review. The faculty advisor and the student prepare and sign an agreement describing the amount and type of work to be accomplished. Either graded or pass/fail.

Use of human cadavers to study prosections of head and neck with emphasis on clinical relevance. Integument, osteology, myology, circulatory systems, lymphatics, oral and dental tissues, neuroanatomy, cranial nerves, general innervation, and salivary glands. Cross-listed with ZOOL 503, may be taken once for credit.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed the following:
  BIOL191 - Biology I: Introduction to Cell and Molecular Biology (FN) (4)
  BIOL192 - Biology II: Introduction to the Diversity of Life (4)

Completed the following:
  BIOL227 - Human Anatomy and Physiology I (FN) (4)
  BIOL228 - Human Anatomy and Physiology II (4)

Description: Focuses on the concepts and processes of animal behavior, with particular emphasis on proximate perspectives. The history of the study of animal behavior, behavioral genetics, the nervous system and behavior, hormones and behavior, ontogeny of behavior, learning and motivation, and other aspects of behavior such as migration, orientation, and navigation will be presented.
Prerequisites:
Completed at least 1 of the following:
BIOL304 - Biology III: Foundations of Ecology and Evolution (4)
BIOL323 - Ecology (4)

Description: Birds as examples of biological principles: classification, identification, ecology, behavior, life histories, distribution, and adaptations of birds. Two weekend field trips.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
BIOL304 - Biology III: Foundations of Ecology and Evolution (4)
BIOL323 - Ecology (4)

Description: Use of human cadavers to study prosections of head and neck with emphasis on clinical relevance. Integument, osteology, myology, circulatory systems, lymphatics, oral and dental tissues, neuroanatomy, cranial nerves, general innervation, and salivary glands.
Prerequisites:
Complete 1 of the following
Completed the following:
  BIOL191 - Biology I: Introduction to Cell and Molecular Biology (FN) (4)
  BIOL192 - Biology II: Introduction to the Diversity of Life (4)

Completed the following:
  BIOL227 - Human Anatomy and Physiology I (FN) (4)
  BIOL228 - Human Anatomy and Physiology II (4)

Description: Herpetology is the branch of zoology that pertains to the study of two ectothermic vertebrate classes: amphibians and reptiles. This course will cover aspects of amphibian and reptilian classification, morphology, adaptation, distribution, anatomy, physiology, behavior, ecology, and conservation. Special emphasis will be placed, particularly with laboratory activities, on local herpetofauna.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
BIOL191 - Biology I: Introduction to Cell and Molecular Biology (FN) (4)
BIOL192 - Biology II: Introduction to the Diversity of Life (4)

Description: Physiological principles common to all forms of animal life with a focus on nutrition are discussed. Physiological adaptations required to live in a variety of environments and deal with a diversity of diets are presented.
Prerequisites:
Completed at least 1 of the following:
BIOL304 - Biology III: Foundations of Ecology and Evolution (4)
BIOL323 - Ecology (4)

Description: Microscopic anatomy of cells, tissues, and organ systems of vertebrates. Major emphasis will be on mammalian systems.
Prerequisites:
Completed at least 1 of the following:
BIOL320 - Cell Biology (3)
ZOOL301 - Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy (4)

Description: Physiological principles common to all forms of animal life are discussed. Physiological adaptations required to live in a variety of environments are presented.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of graduate or higher

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.
Morphology, taxonomy, and natural history of the marine invertebrate animals and terrestrial arthropods exclusive of the insects.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
BIOL191 - Biology I: Introduction to Cell and Molecular Biology (FN) (4)
BIOL192 - Biology II: Introduction to the Diversity of Life (4)

Description: Laboratory for ZOOL 501 Human Physiology. Methods in the functional aspects of human tissues and organ systems with emphasis on regulatory and homeostatic mechanisms.
Co-requisites:
Completed or concurrently enrolled in:
ZOOL501 - Human Physiology (3)

Description: Microscopic anatomy of cells, tissues, and organ systems of vertebrates. Major emphasis will be on mammalian systems.
Prerequisites:
Completed at least 1 of the following:
BIOL320 - Cell Biology (3)
ZOOL301 - Comparative Vertebrate Anatomy (4)

Semester Typically Offered: fall or spring or summer or all
Description: Internship credits are earned in supervised fieldwork specifically related to a student's major. To enroll in courses numbered 293 or 493, a student must have attained a cumulative grade-point average of 2.00 or higher. No more than 12 credits of internship and/or Work U may be applied towards graduation requirements.

An examination of the endocrine system and the hormonal mechanisms associated with social behavior and aggression, reproductive and parental behavior, biological rhythms, etc. Each student is expected to investigate and lead a discussion on an assigned topic.
Prerequisites: Must have a class standing of graduate or higher

Description: The biology of mammals: classification, identification, ecology, reproduction and anatomy, modern data collection methods. Includes an authentic research component.
Prerequisites:
Completed at least 1 of the following:
BIOL304 - Biology III: Foundations of Ecology and Evolution (4)
BIOL323 - Ecology (4)

Description: The general anatomy, physiology and developmental biology of insects, and ecological and evolutionary relationships and interactions of insects with humans. Field trips to collect and identify local species.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
BIOL191 - Biology I: Introduction to Cell and Molecular Biology (FN) (4)
BIOL192 - Biology II: Introduction to the Diversity of Life (4)

Description: Physiology, molecular biology, and clinical aspects of the human endocrine system, with focus on the role of the hypothalamus, pituitary, thyroid, parathyroid, adrenal, gonads, pancreas, and skeleton.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
BIOL320 - Cell Biology (3)

Description: Functional aspects of human tissues and organ systems with emphasis on regulatory and homeostatic mechanisms. Must be taken with ZOOL 411 to fulfill Finishing Foundations requirement.
Prerequisites:
Completed the following:
BIOL310 - Genetics (3)
BIOL320 - Cell Biology (3)
